questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors Explanation: Labetalol is a dual-action beta and alpha blocker, which means it works by blocking both α and β adrenergic receptors. This combination of actions leads to: α?-blockade: Causes vasodilation of arterioles, which lowers peripheral vascular resistance (PVR) and reduces blood pressure. β?- and β?-blockade: Reduces heart rate (β?) and inhibits sympathetic-induced vasodilation in skeletal muscles (β?). The β-blocking effects also reduce the cardiac output. Because of this dual receptor blockade, labetalol is effective in treating hypertension and is often used in conditions like hypertensive emergencies, preeclampsia, or pheochromocytoma. Why the other options are incorrect: B. It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect tachycardia – Incorrect: Labetalol is not a directly acting vasodilator like some other drugs (e.g., hydralazine). The vasodilation occurs through α?-blockade, not a direct smooth muscle relaxant effect. Additionally, the tachycardia is not an indirect effect in this case because β-blockade counters the reflex tachycardia that might otherwise occur with vasodilation. C. It primarily acts as veno dilator with little effect on arterioles – Incorrect: Labetalol's main action is on arterioles (via α?-blockade), not on veins. It does not primarily act as a venodilator. D. It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant vascular smooth muscles – Incorrect: While labetalol does lower peripheral vascular resistance (PVR), it does so primarily by blocking α? receptors (resulting in vasodilation), not by directly relaxing smooth muscle.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes and COPD developed post operative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short term treatment to relieve the symptoms of this person?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bethanechol Explanation: Bethanechol is a muscarinic receptor agonist that directly stimulates the muscarinic receptors in the bladder, promoting bladder contraction and urinary voiding. It is commonly used to treat urinary retention, particularly in cases where there is an underactive bladder due to neurological conditions (such as postoperative urinary retention). In this case, the patient has diabetes (which may lead to neuropathic bladder) and COPD (which doesn’t directly affect urinary retention but could complicate drug choice due to respiratory side effects). Bethanechol is appropriate here as it directly targets the bladder to stimulate voiding without significantly affecting the respiratory system. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Methacholine – Incorrect: Methacholine is a muscarinic agonist but is primarily used as a diagnostic tool for bronchial hyperreactivity in asthma testing (methacholine challenge test). It induces bronchoconstriction, which could worsen COPD symptoms and is not used for urinary retention. C. Terazosin – Incorrect: Terazosin is an α?-adrenergic antagonist that is used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and can relieve urinary retention by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck. However, it is typically not used in postoperative urinary retention, particularly in patients with diabetes and COPD, as its blood pressure-lowering effects can be a concern in certain patients. D. Tamsulosin – Incorrect: Tamsulosin is also an α?-adrenergic antagonist, specifically targeting α?A receptors in the prostate to improve urine flow in BPH. However, it is not indicated for postoperative urinary retention caused by a bladder contraction issue, nor is it suitable in this context when muscarinic receptor stimulation is needed.

questions.text: 70 year old male with BPH and symptoms of urinary urgency is best controlled by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tamsulosin Explanation: In a 70-year-old male with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and symptoms of urinary urgency, the best treatment option is Tamsulosin. Tamsulosin is an α?-adrenergic antagonist that works by selectively blocking α?A receptors in the smooth muscle of the prostate and bladder neck. This results in relaxation of the prostate and bladder neck, improving urinary flow and relieving symptoms such as urgency, frequency, and difficulty in urination. It is specifically effective for men with BPH-related urinary symptoms. Tamsulosin is preferred in this case because it targets the prostate and bladder neck without significantly affecting blood pressure, which can be a concern with other α-blockers. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Should be kept under observation – Incorrect: Observation may be appropriate in cases with very mild symptoms, but given the presence of urinary urgency, treatment is usually warranted to improve the patient's quality of life and prevent complications like urinary retention or infections. C. Prazosin – Incorrect: Prazosin is a non-selective α? antagonist that also works by relaxing smooth muscles to improve urinary flow. However, it can cause hypotension as a side effect, especially in older adults, due to its action on both α?A and α?B receptors. Tamsulosin, being more selective for α?A receptors, is preferred because it causes fewer cardiovascular side effects. D. Atropine – Incorrect: Atropine is an antimuscarinic agent that works by blocking muscarinic receptors, which can be used to treat overactive bladder and urinary urgency. However, it is not effective in BPH because the root cause of urinary urgency in BPH is bladder outlet obstruction due to prostate enlargement, not an issue with detrusor muscle overactivity. Tamsulosin is the better choice for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A female of 28 years of age comes to OPD with complaints of dropping of eyelid in evening time., This patient is almost symptom free in morning and muscle weakness increases during evening time. As a physician you have noticed that patient symptoms improve after neostigmine. What is your most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myasthenia gravis Explanation: The patient's symptoms of drooping eyelid (ptosis) that worsen by evening and improve with neostigmine are characteristic of Myasthenia gravis (MG). Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder caused by the production of antibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This results in muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. In MG, the weakness typically affects the ocular muscles first, leading to ptosis and diplopia (double vision). Symptoms tend to improve after the administration of neostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, which increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. The diurnal variation in symptoms (better in the morning and worse in the evening) is another hallmark feature of Myasthenia gravis, as the neuromuscular junction becomes fatigued over the course of the day. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome – Incorrect: Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is another disorder involving the neuromuscular junction, but it has distinct features. It is caused by autoantibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. LEMS usually presents with proximal muscle weakness (e.g., difficulty standing up from a seated position) and impaired deep tendon reflexes. Unlike MG, LEMS symptoms improve with activity, not worsen. The hallmark of LEMS is the improvement of weakness with exercise, not fatigue during the day. C. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy – Incorrect: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, usually beginning in childhood. It affects large muscle groups, not just the ocular muscles. DMD does not improve with neostigmine, and the symptoms are generally constant, not diurnally variable like in MG. D. Dermatomyositis – Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy characterized by muscle weakness (often proximal) and skin rashes (such as a heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules). While it can cause muscle weakness, it does not typically present with diurnal variation in symptoms, nor does it improve with neostigmine.

questions.text: Drug used to differentiate between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Edrophonium Explanation: Edrophonium is used to differentiate between myasthenia gravis (MG) and cholinergic crisis in patients with neuromuscular disorders. Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that temporarily increases the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. In patients with myasthenia gravis, the administration of edrophonium typically results in rapid improvement of symptoms (such as ptosis and weakness), as it increases acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction. In cholinergic crisis, which is caused by overdose of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (like pyridostigmine), the administration of edrophonium can worsen symptoms, as it further increases acetylcholine levels, leading to excessive cholinergic activity (muscle weakness, respiratory depression, etc.). Thus, edrophonium can be used as a diagnostic tool to distinguish between the two conditions: improvement of symptoms indicates myasthenia gravis, while worsening of symptoms suggests a cholinergic crisis. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Pyridostigmine – Incorrect: Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis, but it does not serve as a diagnostic tool for distinguishing between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis. In fact, overdose of pyridostigmine can lead to a cholinergic crisis. C. Methacholine – Incorrect: Methacholine is a muscarinic receptor agonist used primarily in bronchial challenge tests to diagnose asthma or airway hyperreactivity. It is not used in the diagnosis or differentiation of myasthenia gravis or cholinergic crisis. D. Clonidine – Incorrect: Clonidine is an α?-adrenergic agonist used primarily in the treatment of hypertension and opioid withdrawal. It has no role in differentiating between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis.

questions.text: A boy is planning to travel by bus. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent motion sickness in this person?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Promethazine Explanation: Promethazine is an antihistamine that is commonly used to prevent motion sickness. It works by blocking histamine receptors (H? receptors) in the brain, which are involved in the sensation of nausea and vomiting. Promethazine has anticholinergic properties as well, which help to prevent the nausea and dizziness associated with motion sickness. Promethazine is effective in preventing and treating motion sickness, and is typically used before travel to minimize symptoms. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Cetirizine – Incorrect: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine, commonly used for allergic reactions (like hay fever, urticaria) due to its non-sedating properties. While it can block histamine, it is not specifically used for motion sickness, as it doesn't have the same sedative or anticholinergic effects needed for preventing nausea. C. Loratadine – Incorrect: Loratadine is also a second-generation antihistamine, which is non-sedating and typically used for allergic conditions. Like cetirizine, it does not have the necessary properties to prevent motion sickness, as it lacks the anticholinergic effect necessary to address the nausea and dizziness caused by motion. D. Fexofenadine – Incorrect: Fexofenadine is another second-generation antihistamine that is primarily used to treat allergic symptoms, such as rhinoconjunctivitis and urticaria. Similar to cetirizine and loratadine, it does not have sufficient anticholinergic properties to effectively treat or prevent motion sickness.

questions.text: Pirenzepine is used in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gastric ulcer Explanation: Pirenzepine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that selectively blocks the M1 muscarinic receptors found in the gastric parietal cells. This action inhibits gastric acid secretion, which is useful in the treatment of gastric ulcers. By reducing acid secretion, pirenzepine helps in the healing of gastric ulcers and reduces the symptoms associated with acid reflux or irritation from excessive stomach acid. It is used in the management of gastric ulcers and related conditions like peptic ulcers, where acid reduction is beneficial in promoting healing. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Motion sickness – Incorrect: Pirenzepine is not used for motion sickness. The treatment for motion sickness typically involves antihistamines (e.g., promethazine) or anticholinergics (e.g., scopolamine), which target different receptors and pathways to prevent nausea and dizziness associated with motion. C. Bradycardia – Incorrect: Pirenzepine does not affect heart rate directly and is not used to treat bradycardia. Atropine is the drug typically used in cases of bradycardia as it blocks the M2 muscarinic receptors in the heart, resulting in an increased heart rate. D. Tachycardia – Incorrect: Pirenzepine is not used to treat tachycardia. Treatment for tachycardia depends on the underlying cause but may involve beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, or other agents, rather than a muscarinic receptor antagonist like pirenzepine.

questions.text: A lady was stung by many bees. She developed breathing difficulty and hypotension. Drug useful for treating this condition is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Adrenaline Explanation: The lady who was stung by many bees and developed breathing difficulty and hypotension is likely experiencing a severe allergic reaction or anaphylaxis, which can occur after insect stings like bee stings. Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening allergic reaction that involves airway constriction, hypotension, and other systemic effects. The drug of choice to treat anaphylaxis is adrenaline (epinephrine). Adrenaline works by: Bronchodilation, which helps relieve breathing difficulty. Vasoconstriction, which helps increase blood pressure and reverse hypotension. Reducing inflammation and other symptoms by acting on various receptors (alpha and beta receptors). Adrenaline is typically administered intramuscularly in the thigh in cases of severe anaphylaxis. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Noradrenaline (Norepinephrine) – Incorrect: Norepinephrine primarily acts as a vasoconstrictor (alpha-1 agonist) to raise blood pressure, but it does not have the bronchodilatory effects required to manage the breathing difficulty associated with anaphylaxis. Therefore, adrenaline is preferred over norepinephrine in this scenario. C. Dopamine – Incorrect: Dopamine can be used to increase blood pressure in cases of shock, but it does not address the bronchoconstriction and other symptoms of anaphylaxis. It is not the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis, where adrenaline is preferred due to its broader therapeutic effects. D. Isoprenaline – Incorrect: Isoprenaline is a beta-agonist that primarily causes bronchodilation and increased heart rate. While it may help with breathing difficulty, it does not provide vasoconstriction and may not be effective for hypotension in anaphylaxis. Adrenaline, which has both alpha and beta effects, is much more effective in treating anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the action of dopamine at low doses?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It increases renal blood flow Explanation: At low doses, dopamine primarily acts on dopaminergic receptors (D1 receptors), leading to vasodilation in specific vascular beds, particularly in the renal, mesenteric, and coronary circulations. This effect helps increase renal blood flow, which can be beneficial in conditions like acute kidney injury or shock to maintain renal perfusion. The increase in renal blood flow is one of the primary effects of dopamine at low doses, which is why it is used in certain clinical settings to support renal function. Why the other options are incorrect: B. It produces positive chronotropic action – Incorrect: Dopamine at low doses does not significantly affect heart rate. At higher doses, dopamine can stimulate beta-1 adrenergic receptors, leading to positive chronotropic (increased heart rate) and inotropic (increased contractility) effects. However, these effects are more pronounced at moderate to high doses, not at low doses. C. It causes vasoconstriction – Incorrect: At low doses, dopamine does not cause significant vasoconstriction. It primarily causes vasodilation in the renal and mesenteric vessels. Vasoconstriction occurs at higher doses when dopamine stimulates alpha-adrenergic receptors, which leads to increased blood pressure. D. It causes hypotension – Incorrect: At low doses, dopamine typically does not cause hypotension. It may cause a slight increase in blood pressure due to vasodilation in the renal and mesenteric vessels. Hypotension may occur at very low doses or in cases of severe shock, but at low doses, dopamine is more likely to help improve blood flow to the kidneys rather than reduce blood pressure.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of limb muscle especially in the evening after work. These symptoms improved after edrophonium test. This patient is likely suffering from which one of the following condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myasthenia gravis Explanation: The patient who presents with weakness of limb muscles, especially in the evening after work, and shows improvement after the edrophonium test is likely suffering from myasthenia gravis (MG). Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that leads to muscle weakness, which often worsens with activity (fatigue) and improves with rest. This condition is caused by antibodies that block or destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing effective muscle contraction. The edrophonium test (a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which improves muscle strength in myasthenia gravis patients. This improvement is characteristic of MG. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Lambert Eaton syndrome – Incorrect: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is also a neuromuscular disorder, but it is caused by autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, impairing the release of acetylcholine. The weakness in LEMS is usually more prominent in the proximal muscles (e.g., thighs, shoulders) and tends to improve with muscle use, which is the opposite of myasthenia gravis. The edrophonium test does not show the same improvement as in MG. C. Bronchial asthma – Incorrect: Bronchial asthma is a respiratory condition characterized by airway constriction and wheezing due to inflammation and bronchospasm. While asthma can cause shortness of breath and weakness, it does not cause muscle weakness that improves with an edrophonium test. Asthma is unrelated to neuromuscular junction disorders. D. Guillain-Barré syndrome – Incorrect: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute inflammatory demyelinating disorder of the peripheral nervous system, typically triggered by an infection. It leads to ascending muscle weakness, which progresses rapidly. While GBS causes weakness, it does not improve with the edrophonium test. The condition is typically characterized by progressive paralysis and sensory disturbances, rather than the fluctuating weakness seen in myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: After eating an unknown plant, a child was presented to the emergency with comatose status. The pupil were dilated and skin was dry. Body temperature was raised and the heart rate was high. These signs and symptoms can occur with the intake of which of the following substance?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dhatura Explanation: The symptoms described in the question—dilated pupils, dry skin, elevated body temperature, and high heart rate—are consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. These symptoms are typically caused by the ingestion of substances that contain anticholinergic compounds. Dhatura (Datura stramonium) is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties, which can cause delirium, hallucinations, dilated pupils, dry mouth, increased heart rate, elevated body temperature, and skin dryness. The alkaloids in dhatura (e.g., scopolamine, hyoscyamine) inhibit acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, leading to these characteristic toxic effects. In severe cases, dhatura poisoning can result in coma and death due to its systemic effects. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Foxglove – Incorrect: Foxglove (digitalis) contains compounds called cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to arrhythmias and bradycardia (slow heart rate), not symptoms like dry skin, elevated body temperature, or dilated pupils. The symptoms described are more characteristic of anticholinergic poisoning, not digitalis toxicity. B. Poppy seeds – Incorrect: Poppy seeds contain trace amounts of opioid alkaloids (such as morphine and codeine), but they are not known to cause the anticholinergic symptoms of dilated pupils, dry skin, and elevated body temperature. Opioid toxicity would cause miosis (constricted pupils), respiratory depression, and bradycardia, not the signs mentioned in the question. C. Cannabinoid – Incorrect: Cannabinoids (such as those found in marijuana) generally cause euphoria, drowsiness, increased heart rate, and conjunctival injection (red eyes), but they do not typically produce the anticholinergic symptoms described. While cannabinoid toxicity can lead to altered mental status, it does not typically cause dilated pupils and dry skin as seen with dhatura poisoning.

questions.text: A farmer is presented to the emergency with garlic odour breathing, pin point pupil and excessive salivary secretion. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating this poisoning?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Atropine Explanation: The farmer presenting with garlic odor breathing, pinpoint pupils, and excessive salivation is likely suffering from organophosphate poisoning or cholinergic toxicity. The symptoms are typical of exposure to substances that inhibit acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors. Garlic odor can be a sign of exposure to organophosphates or phosphorus-based pesticides. Pinpoint pupils (miosis), excessive salivation, sweating, and other cholinergic symptoms (such as diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting) are consistent with cholinergic crisis caused by organophosphate toxicity. Atropine is the drug of choice for treating organophosphate poisoning because it is a muscarinic antagonist that blocks the effects of excess acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, helping to alleviate symptoms such as bradycardia, salivation, and miosis. In severe cases, pralidoxime (PAM) may also be used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase, but atropine is the mainstay for managing the cholinergic effects in this situation. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Flumazenil – Incorrect: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist, used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose. It has no role in treating organophosphate poisoning or cholinergic toxicity. B. Pralidoxime – Incorrect: Pralidoxime is an acetylcholinesterase reactivator that can be used as an adjunct to atropine in organophosphate poisoning. However, it is not the first-line drug. Atropine is the primary treatment to counteract muscarinic symptoms, while pralidoxime is typically used when there is a need to reverse the nicotinic effects (such as muscle weakness) or to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. In this case, atropine is the correct answer. D. N-acetylcysteine – Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is used in acetaminophen (paracetamol) overdose to replenish glutathione and prevent liver damage. It has no role in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning or cholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: An elderly male patient developed dementia and was diagnosed as Alzheimer’s disease. Which neurotransmitter level is reduced in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Acetylcholine Explanation: In Alzheimer's disease, one of the hallmark features is the degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the brain, particularly those that project to areas like the hippocampus and cortex, which are involved in memory and cognition. As a result, there is a reduction in acetylcholine levels, a neurotransmitter crucial for memory, learning, and cognitive function. Acetylcholine plays a key role in synaptic transmission in the brain, and its deficiency in Alzheimer’s disease contributes to the cognitive decline and memory impairment seen in these patients. Cholinesterase inhibitors (such as donepezil) are often used to help increase acetylcholine levels in the brain, improving symptoms or slowing the progression of cognitive decline in Alzheimer's patients. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Dopamine – Incorrect: Dopamine is associated with movement regulation and is primarily implicated in diseases like Parkinson’s disease and schizophrenia, not Alzheimer's disease. Although dopamine levels can be affected in various neurodegenerative diseases, reduced acetylcholine is the hallmark neurotransmitter deficiency in Alzheimer’s. B. Serotonin – Incorrect: Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, appetite, and sleep, and its levels can be altered in disorders like depression and anxiety. While there may be some serotonergic involvement in Alzheimer’s, acetylcholine is the key neurotransmitter that is significantly reduced in Alzheimer's disease. C. Adrenaline – Incorrect: Adrenaline (epinephrine) is involved in the fight or flight response and is primarily related to the sympathetic nervous system. It is not specifically involved in Alzheimer’s disease, where the problem lies primarily with acetylcholine in the brain.

questions.text: A deep vein thrombosis patient was started on an anticoagulant therapy. Next day, the patient presented with the features shown in the diagram below. Likely drug implicated for this adverse effect is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Warfarin Explanation: The patient likely developed an adverse effect related to warfarin therapy, given the context of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and anticoagulant use. One of the key adverse effects of warfarin is skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome, which is a known complication, particularly in the early days of treatment. Warfarin works by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and can lead to a hypercoagulable state initially (before the anticoagulant effect fully kicks in). This can cause thrombosis in small vessels, leading to skin necrosis. This adverse effect typically occurs within the first few days of treatment and is more common in patients with protein C or S deficiency, as these proteins are natural anticoagulants, and their inhibition by warfarin can cause an increased risk of clot formation. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Heparin – Incorrect: Heparin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is commonly used in the hospital setting for DVT treatment. It can cause heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), but it does not commonly cause the type of skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome seen with warfarin. HIT can lead to thrombosis, but not the same cutaneous symptoms as warfarin. B. Rivaroxaban – Incorrect: Rivaroxaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that inhibits Factor Xa. While DOACs have their own risk of bleeding and thrombosis, they are not commonly associated with the same skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome seen with warfarin. D. Dabigatran – Incorrect: Dabigatran is another DOAC, this one inhibiting thrombin (Factor II). While it has anticoagulant effects, it is not associated with skin necrosis or the early hypercoagulable state seen with warfarin. Like rivaroxaban, it does not produce the same complications as warfarin.

questions.text: Which of the following hypolipidemic drug acts by inhibition of PCSK-9?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Evolocumab Explanation: Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor that works by inhibiting the PCSK-9 protein, which normally binds to and degrades LDL receptors (low-density lipoprotein receptors) on the liver. By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of LDL receptors available to clear LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream, thereby significantly lowering LDL cholesterol levels. This class of drugs is used in patients with hyperlipidemia, especially those who do not respond adequately to statins or those with familial hypercholesterolemia. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Atorvastatin – Incorrect: Atorvastatin is a statin, which works by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the enzyme responsible for the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis in the liver. It reduces cholesterol production, which in turn leads to increased expression of LDL receptors and decreased LDL cholesterol levels. However, atorvastatin does not work by inhibiting PCSK-9. C. Ezetimibe – Incorrect: Ezetimibe works by inhibiting the NPC1L1 protein, which is involved in the absorption of cholesterol from the intestine. By reducing cholesterol absorption, it helps lower total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol levels. However, it does not target PCSK-9. D. Fenofibrate – Incorrect: Fenofibrate is a fibrate that primarily acts by activating PPAR-alpha, leading to increased oxidation of fatty acids and reduced triglyceride levels. It can also modestly increase HDL cholesterol but does not affect PCSK-9.

questions.text: A 36 week pregnant patient on warfarin. INR level is 3.Best Course of action would be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Stop warfarin and switch to heparin Explanation: In a pregnant patient, warfarin is generally contraindicated, especially after the first trimester due to its teratogenic effects (it can cause fetal bleeding, cranial malformations, and other complications). Although the patient is currently on warfarin and has an INR of 3, which is within the therapeutic range for anticoagulation, warfarin should be discontinued immediately in pregnancy. The best course of action in this case is to stop warfarin and switch to heparin, which is the preferred anticoagulant during pregnancy. Heparin (both unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin) does not cross the placenta and is safe for the fetus. Additionally, heparin can provide adequate anticoagulation, and the patient's INR should be monitored while transitioning to heparin therapy. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Add aspirin – Incorrect: Aspirin is not typically used as a sole anticoagulant in pregnancy, particularly in this case, where the patient is on warfarin and has an elevated INR. Adding aspirin alone is not sufficient for anticoagulation, especially in patients requiring a more effective therapy for conditions like deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. B. Aspirin + Heparin – Incorrect: While heparin is appropriate for anticoagulation during pregnancy, adding aspirin is typically used in specific conditions like preeclampsia, recurrent pregnancy loss, or for antiplatelet effects in certain cardiovascular conditions. It is not needed in this case, and the priority should be stopping warfarin and starting heparin. C. Continue warfarin – Incorrect: Continuing warfarin is not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, due to the risk of fetal bleeding and teratogenicity. The best approach is to stop warfarin immediately and switch to heparin.

questions.text: Drug useful for ventricular tachycardia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IV Amiodarone Explanation: IV Amiodarone is the drug of choice for the acute management of ventricular tachycardia (VT). It is a class III antiarrhythmic that works by prolonging the action potential duration and refractory period in the heart, thereby stabilizing abnormal electrical activity in the ventricles. It is particularly useful in life-threatening arrhythmias like ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. IV amiodarone is typically used in emergency settings, especially when VT is hemodynamically unstable or persistent. It can be administered intravenously in acute situations to rapidly correct the arrhythmia. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Oral Amiodarone – Incorrect: Oral amiodarone is used for chronic management of arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation and for prevention of recurrent ventricular arrhythmias, but it is not suitable for acute management of ventricular tachycardia. In emergencies, the rapid action of IV amiodarone is preferred. C. IV Beta Blocker – Incorrect: IV beta blockers are sometimes used for supraventricular tachycardias or to manage atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, but they are not the first-line treatment for ventricular tachycardia. Beta blockers do not have the same efficacy in controlling ventricular arrhythmias compared to amiodarone. D. Oral Beta Blocker – Incorrect: Oral beta blockers are used for long-term control of arrhythmias, but they are not effective in the acute management of ventricular tachycardia. They may be helpful in preventing recurrent arrhythmias after the acute episode has been managed, but IV amiodarone is preferred in emergencies.

questions.text: DOC for digitalis induced Ventricular tachycardia is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lidocaine Explanation: Lidocaine is the drug of choice (DOC) for digitalis-induced ventricular tachycardia. It is a Class IB antiarrhythmic that is particularly effective in ventricular arrhythmias, especially those associated with digoxin toxicity. Lidocaine acts by blocking sodium channels, especially in ischemic or depolarized ventricular tissue, and it suppresses ectopic pacemakers. It does not increase AV nodal conduction, which is crucial because increasing conduction in digoxin toxicity can worsen the arrhythmia. Moreover, lidocaine is less likely to depress AV conduction, making it safer in the context of digitalis toxicity. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Reducing dosage of digoxin – Incorrect: While reducing or stopping digoxin is necessary in toxicity, it is not sufficient alone to treat life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias. Active pharmacologic intervention with lidocaine or other agents is needed in acute settings. C. Verapamil – Incorrect: Verapamil, a calcium channel blocker, is contraindicated in digitalis toxicity, as it can worsen heart block and may increase digoxin levels, making arrhythmias worse. D. Beta blockers – Incorrect: Beta blockers can slow AV conduction and may help in some supraventricular arrhythmias, but they are not preferred in digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias, and can also worsen bradyarrhythmias or heart block associated with digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a late inward sodium channel blocker?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ranolazine Explanation: Ranolazine is a unique anti-anginal drug that works by inhibiting the late inward sodium current (late INa) in cardiac myocytes. In ischemic conditions, increased late sodium influx leads to sodium and calcium overload inside myocardial cells. This intracellular calcium overload increases diastolic wall tension, worsens myocardial oxygen demand, and impairs relaxation (diastolic dysfunction). Ranolazine, by blocking late Na? channels, reduces calcium overload indirectly (via the Na?/Ca²? exchanger) and thus improves myocardial relaxation and reduces oxygen consumption, without affecting heart rate or blood pressure. This mechanism makes ranolazine especially useful in chronic stable angina, particularly when conventional therapies are not well tolerated. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Ivabradine – Incorrect: Ivabradine selectively inhibits the funny current (If) in the sinoatrial (SA) node, leading to heart rate reduction without affecting contractility or blood pressure. It does not block late sodium channels. C. Trimetazidine – Incorrect: Trimetazidine is a metabolic modulator used in angina. It shifts myocardial energy metabolism from fatty acid oxidation to glucose oxidation, which is more oxygen-efficient. It does not affect sodium channels. D. Fasudil – Incorrect: Fasudil is a Rho-kinase inhibitor used in pulmonary hypertension and cerebral vasospasm. It works by causing vasodilation but has no effect on sodium channels.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drug is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Amiodarone Explanation: Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug widely used for treating both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. However, it has several serious long-term side effects, the most significant being pulmonary toxicity. Pulmonary toxicity is one of the most dangerous adverse effects of amiodarone, and it can present as interstitial pneumonitis, pulmonary fibrosis, or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). In patients with pre-existing interstitial lung disease (ILD), the risk of amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity is significantly increased, and its use can worsen respiratory function. Therefore, amiodarone is contraindicated in patients with ILD or significant pulmonary disease. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Sotalol – Incorrect: Sotalol is also a Class III antiarrhythmic but lacks the pulmonary toxicity seen with amiodarone. It has beta-blocker activity and is generally safe in patients without significant cardiac or renal contraindications. It is not contraindicated in ILD. C. Quinidine – Incorrect: Quinidine is a Class Ia antiarrhythmic. Its adverse effects include QT prolongation, cinchonism, and GI disturbances, but not pulmonary toxicity. It is not contraindicated in ILD. D. Lignocaine (Lidocaine) – Incorrect: Lignocaine is a Class Ib antiarrhythmic, used mainly for ventricular arrhythmias, especially in emergency settings. It does not cause lung toxicity and is safe in patients with ILD.

questions.text: A patient with ECG changes of MI underwent CABG. What will you add on to the list along with aspirin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) P2Y12 Inhibitor Explanation: In a patient who has experienced a myocardial infarction (MI) and undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), it is essential to use dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) for optimal secondary prevention of future cardiovascular events. Aspirin is a cornerstone of antiplatelet therapy. P2Y12 inhibitors (such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) are added to aspirin in post-MI patients, even after CABG, especially when there is concern for graft patency or ongoing risk of thrombosis. Clinical guidelines recommend aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor as dual therapy in patients with MI, particularly those undergoing PCI or CABG depending on individual bleeding and thrombotic risk. Why the other options are incorrect: A. PDE 5 inhibitor – Incorrect: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil) are used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension. They have no role in post-MI or CABG antiplatelet management, and can be dangerous when combined with nitrates due to risk of severe hypotension. B. Dabigatran – Incorrect: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (anticoagulant) used for atrial fibrillation and venous thromboembolism (VTE) prevention. It is not used in the standard treatment of MI post-CABG unless there's a separate indication for anticoagulation (e.g., AF). D. PDE 3 inhibitor – Incorrect: PDE-3 inhibitors (e.g., milrinone, cilostazol) are used in heart failure or intermittent claudication, not for post-MI antiplatelet therapy. They do not replace or enhance the effects of aspirin and are not indicated after CABG for MI.

questions.text: A women used aspirin for arthritis for pain relief for years. Later she developed intestinal bleed which occurs due to inhibition of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thromboxane Explanation: Aspirin is a non-selective, irreversible inhibitor of the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2). This enzyme is crucial for the synthesis of prostaglandins and thromboxane A?. In the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, COX-1 normally helps produce protective prostaglandins that maintain mucosal blood flow, mucus secretion, and bicarbonate production. Chronic use of aspirin inhibits COX-1, leading to reduced prostaglandin synthesis, which compromises the protective mucosal barrier. Additionally, inhibition of thromboxane A? (produced by platelets via COX-1) reduces platelet aggregation, increasing the risk of bleeding, especially from areas like the stomach and intestines that are already vulnerable due to mucosal injury. Therefore, inhibition of thromboxane A? contributes to intestinal bleeding by impairing platelet aggregation and hemostasis. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Leukotriene – Incorrect: Leukotrienes are products of the lipoxygenase pathway, not the cyclooxygenase pathway. Aspirin does not inhibit leukotriene synthesis. In fact, shunting of arachidonic acid metabolism toward leukotriene production may cause bronchospasm in aspirin-sensitive asthma, but not GI bleeding. C. Bradykinin – Incorrect: Bradykinin is a vasoactive peptide involved in pain, inflammation, and vascular permeability. It is not directly affected by aspirin and does not play a key role in mucosal protection or bleeding related to NSAIDs. D. Hageman factor – Incorrect: Hageman factor (Factor XII) is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation. Aspirin does not affect this clotting factor, and it is not implicated in the GI bleeding associated with NSAID use.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of apixaban?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Direct factor Xa inhibitor Explanation: Apixaban is an oral anticoagulant that works by directly inhibiting Factor Xa, a key enzyme in the coagulation cascade. Factor Xa is responsible for converting prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa). Thrombin then converts fibrinogen to fibrin, leading to clot formation. By inhibiting Factor Xa, apixaban reduces thrombin generation and prevents the formation of fibrin clots. Apixaban is used in conditions like: Atrial fibrillation (to prevent stroke), Deep vein thrombosis (DVT), Pulmonary embolism (PE), And for thromboprophylaxis after orthopedic surgery. It is a direct-acting oral anticoagulant (DOAC) and does not require routine INR monitoring, unlike warfarin. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) receptor inhibitors – Incorrect: This refers to drugs like clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticagrelor, which inhibit the P2Y12 receptor on platelets, preventing aggregation. These are antiplatelet agents, not anticoagulants like apixaban. C. Glycoprotein IIB/IIIA inhibitors – Incorrect: Drugs like abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban block the GPIIb/IIIa receptor on platelets, inhibiting fibrinogen binding and aggregation. These are used primarily in acute coronary syndromes, and again are antiplatelet, not anticoagulant drugs. D. Adenosine reuptake inhibitors – Incorrect: Dipyridamole is an example, which increases adenosine levels and inhibits platelet function. It is also an antiplatelet agent used sometimes in stroke prevention.

questions.text: A hypertensive woman who wants to conceive. Which medicine needs to be stopped?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ACEI (Angiotensin Converting Enzyme Inhibitors) Explanation: ACE inhibitors (such as enalapril, lisinopril, ramipril) are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects, especially during the second and third trimesters. They can lead to: Fetal renal dysgenesis Oligohydramnios Pulmonary hypoplasia Intrauterine growth restriction Skull hypoplasia Neonatal renal failure and death Because of these serious fetal risks, ACE inhibitors must be discontinued in any hypertensive woman who is planning to conceive or becomes pregnant. They are classified as Category D (positive evidence of human fetal risk) in pregnancy. Safe alternatives during pregnancy include: Labetalol Methyldopa Nifedipine Hydralazine (typically in acute settings) Why the other options are incorrect: B. CCB (Calcium Channel Blockers) – Incorrect: Nifedipine and other dihydropyridine CCBs are generally safe in pregnancy and are commonly used to manage hypertension in pregnant women. C. Hydralazine – Incorrect: Hydralazine is a vasodilator that is safe and effective in pregnancy, especially in managing acute severe hypertension. D. Metoprolol – Incorrect: While beta-blockers can have some fetal effects (e.g. intrauterine growth restriction), selective beta-1 blockers like metoprolol are often considered relatively safe in pregnancy, especially if alternatives are not tolerated. However, labetalol is usually preferred.

questions.text: A patient presented to hospital after consuming 8 tablets of 0.25 mg digoxin. His ECG shows ST depression and QT changes. What should be the initial management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Digoxin immune Fab Explanation: The patient has acute digoxin toxicity, which is evident from: History of ingestion of 8 tablets of 0.25 mg digoxin (total dose = 2 mg, which is toxic), ECG changes consistent with digoxin effect (e.g., scooped ST depression, QT shortening, and possible arrhythmias). The first-line and most effective treatment for life-threatening or severe digoxin toxicity is Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Digoxin immune Fab), which: Bind to digoxin in the blood, Form a complex that is excreted by the kidneys, Rapidly reverse toxic cardiac and systemic effects. Indications for Digoxin immune Fab include: Life-threatening arrhythmias, Significant hyperkalemia, Ingestion of a large amount of digoxin, High serum digoxin level in a symptomatic patient. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Lignocaine – Incorrect: Lignocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic that may be used in some ventricular arrhythmias, but it is not the initial or definitive treatment for digoxin toxicity. It is secondary to Fab fragments. C. Intravenous Adenosine – Incorrect: Adenosine is used to treat paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). It is contraindicated in digoxin-induced arrhythmias, especially atrial tachycardia with block, as it may precipitate complete heart block or ventricular fibrillation. D. Sublingual nitroglycerine – Incorrect: Nitroglycerine is used for angina and coronary artery spasm, not for digoxin toxicity. It has no role in treating digoxin overdose.

questions.text: Drugs providing relief from Cardiac remodelling and increasing longevity ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metoprolol Explanation: Metoprolol, a beta-1 selective beta-blocker, plays a critical role in chronic heart failure management. It provides relief from cardiac remodeling and has been proven to increase survival (longevity) in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Mechanism: In chronic heart failure, sympathetic overactivity contributes to progressive cardiac remodeling and deterioration. Beta-blockers like metoprolol reduce heart rate, decrease myocardial oxygen demand, and block the harmful effects of chronic catecholamine stimulation, which slows or reverses cardiac remodeling. They also reduce mortality and hospitalizations in heart failure patients (as shown in trials like MERIT-HF). Other beta-blockers with proven mortality benefit in heart failure include: Bisoprolol Carvedilol Why the other options are incorrect: B. Torsemide – Incorrect: Torsemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic relief of fluid overload in heart failure but does not prevent remodeling or improve survival. It provides symptomatic benefit only. C. Prazosin – Incorrect: Prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker used for hypertension and sometimes BPH. It is not used in heart failure due to lack of benefit on mortality and may cause hypotension. D. Furosemide – Incorrect: Like torsemide, furosemide is a loop diuretic that helps manage fluid overload in heart failure. However, it has no effect on cardiac remodeling or survival.

questions.text: Sacubitril used in congestive heart failure works by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Inhibitor of neutral endopeptidase Explanation: Sacubitril is a neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase) inhibitor that is used in combination with valsartan (an angiotensin receptor blocker) in the management of chronic congestive heart failure—specifically heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Mechanism of Action: Neprilysin is an enzyme that breaks down natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, and adrenomedullin—all of which have beneficial effects in heart failure (vasodilation, natriuresis, diuresis, and inhibition of cardiac fibrosis and remodeling). Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, thereby increasing the levels of these beneficial peptides, which helps to reduce preload and afterload, improve cardiac output, and slow progression of heart failure. When combined with valsartan (as in sacubitril/valsartan, brand name Entresto), the drug also blocks the harmful RAAS pathway, offering dual benefit: Natriuretic peptide enhancement (via sacubitril) RAAS inhibition (via valsartan) Clinical trials like PARADIGM-HF showed this combination reduces mortality and hospitalizations in heart failure patients better than ACE inhibitors alone. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Renin agonist – Incorrect: Sacubitril does not act on renin directly. A renin agonist would enhance the RAAS pathway, which is harmful in heart failure. C. Aldosterone inhibitor – Incorrect: Aldosterone inhibitors (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) do help in heart failure but sacubitril is not one. It acts via neprilysin inhibition. D. Endothelin agonist – Incorrect: Endothelin agonists cause vasoconstriction, which would worsen heart failure. Sacubitril does not act on the endothelin system.

questions.text: In which of the following drugs coagulation monitoring is required?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Heparin Explanation: Unfractionated heparin (UFH) is an anticoagulant that requires coagulation monitoring, typically via the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). This is because: UFH has unpredictable pharmacokinetics due to variable binding to plasma proteins, leading to variable anticoagulant responses among individuals. Monitoring ensures the dose is therapeutic (not too low to be ineffective, or too high causing bleeding). aPTT is usually maintained at 1.5–2.5 times the normal value during therapy. UFH is commonly used in: Acute coronary syndromes Venous thromboembolism During and after surgeries requiring anticoagulation Why the other options are incorrect: A. Dabigatran – Incorrect: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (NOAC). It has predictable pharmacokinetics and does not require routine coagulation monitoring. In certain emergencies or renal impairment, specialized assays (e.g., TT, ECT) may be used, but routine monitoring is not needed. B. Enoxaparin – Incorrect: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) with predictable dose-response. Routine monitoring is not required in most patients, though anti-Xa level monitoring may be done in pregnancy, renal failure, or obesity. C. Fondaparinux – Incorrect: Fondaparinux is a synthetic factor Xa inhibitor with stable pharmacokinetics. It also does not require routine coagulation monitoring under normal conditions.

questions.text: Which drug acts on letter mentioned 2?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Aliskiren Explanation: The question references "letter 2", which in context typically refers to a diagram of the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) — a key hormonal system regulating blood pressure and fluid balance. Let’s assume "2" marks the site of renin activity, where angiotensinogen is converted to angiotensin I. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. It blocks renin's action at this early step, thus inhibiting the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, and subsequently reducing the formation of angiotensin II and aldosterone downstream. This leads to: Vasodilation Reduced sodium and water retention Lowered blood pressure Since site 2 refers to the renin action point, Aliskiren is the drug that acts at that site. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Enalapril – Incorrect: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor. It inhibits the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II (site 3 in the typical RAAS diagram), not site 2. B. Telmisartan – Incorrect: Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). It blocks the action of angiotensin II on AT1 receptors (site 4 in the pathway), not site 2. D. Eplerenone – Incorrect: Eplerenone is a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist. It acts at the level of aldosterone receptors in the kidney (site 5 in the pathway), not at site 2.

questions.text: Find out the site of actions of thiazide diuretics
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Site 3 Explanation: Thiazide diuretics act in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron. In commonly used nephron diagrams, site 3 typically refers to the DCT, making option C the correct answer. Mechanism of Action of Thiazide Diuretics: Thiazides (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone) inhibit the Na?/Cl? symporter in the early distal convoluted tubule. This results in increased excretion of sodium and chloride, leading to increased water excretion. Also causes mild potassium loss and increased calcium reabsorption. Clinical uses include: Hypertension Edema due to heart failure or liver/kidney disease Nephrolithiasis due to hypercalciuria Why other options are incorrect: A. Site 1 – Incorrect: Refers to the proximal convoluted tubule. This is the site of action of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide, not thiazides. B. Site 2 – Incorrect: Refers to the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This is the site of action of loop diuretics like furosemide. D. Site 4 – Incorrect: Refers to the collecting duct, where potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., spironolactone, amiloride) act.

questions.text: At a high altitude of 3000 m, a person complains of breathlessnes. All of the following can be used for management of this person except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Intravenous digoxin Explanation: A person at high altitude (~3000 m) experiencing breathlessness is likely suffering from acute mountain sickness (AMS) or its severe forms like high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE). This condition results from hypobaric hypoxia (low oxygen pressure), leading to symptoms like headache, breathlessness, fatigue, and sometimes pulmonary or cerebral edema. Correct management strategies include: Oxygen supplementation (Option B): Increases arterial oxygen levels and is one of the most effective immediate interventions for high-altitude illness. Immediate descent (Option C): The most definitive and life-saving measure in moderate to severe cases. Removing the person from the hypoxic environment is essential. Acetazolamide (Option D): A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used for prophylaxis and treatment of AMS. It promotes acclimatization by causing a mild metabolic acidosis that stimulates ventilation. Why Option A is Incorrect (and thus the correct answer to the question): Intravenous digoxin is not indicated in the management of high-altitude illness. Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and certain arrhythmias, but has no role in treating hypoxia or altitude-related symptoms. Its use could be harmful due to potential toxicity, especially in a setting of dehydration or electrolyte disturbances common at high altitude.

questions.text: Which of the following is an orally acting direct Xa inhibitor
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rivaroxaban Explanation: Rivaroxaban is a direct Factor Xa inhibitor that is orally administered. It works by selectively inhibiting Factor Xa, a key enzyme in the coagulation cascade responsible for converting prothrombin to thrombin. By inhibiting Xa, rivaroxaban prevents thrombin generation and clot formation. Used in stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and pulmonary embolism (PE). It is part of the class of drugs known as DOACs (Direct Oral Anticoagulants). Why the other options are incorrect: B. Agartaban — Incorrect: Likely a misspelling or confusion with Argatroban, which is a direct thrombin inhibitor (not Xa inhibitor) and is administered intravenously, not orally. C. Dabigatran — Incorrect: A direct thrombin (Factor IIa) inhibitor, not a Xa inhibitor. It is orally active, but does not inhibit Factor Xa. D. Bivalirudin — Incorrect: A parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor used mainly during percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI). Not a Xa inhibitor and not orally administered.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug used to treat SIADH
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tolvaptan Explanation: Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion (SIADH) is a condition characterized by excess ADH (vasopressin) leading to water retention, hyponatremia, and low serum osmolality. Tolvaptan is a vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that works by: Blocking the action of ADH in the renal collecting ducts. Promoting free water excretion (aquaresis) without loss of sodium or other electrolytes. Increasing serum sodium levels — which is crucial in treating SIADH. Tolvaptan is orally active and specifically indicated for euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia, such as that caused by SIADH. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Desmopressin — Incorrect: A synthetic analog of ADH, used to treat diabetes insipidus and certain bleeding disorders. It worsens SIADH by increasing water retention. C. Von Willebrand factor — Incorrect: A clotting protein, used in von Willebrand disease and hemophilia A. Has no role in water or sodium balance or the management of SIADH. D. Terlipressin — Incorrect: A vasopressin analog used in variceal bleeding and hepatorenal syndrome. Like desmopressin, it would exacerbate SIADH by increasing water retention.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-dyslipidemic drug work by stimulating PPAR alpha ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gemfibrozil Explanation: Gemfibrozil is a fibrate class drug used to treat hypertriglyceridemia. It works primarily by activating PPAR-α (Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor Alpha), a nuclear receptor that regulates gene expression involved in lipid metabolism. Mechanism of action of Gemfibrozil (via PPAR-α activation): Increases expression of lipoprotein lipase, enhancing the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Increases fatty acid oxidation in liver and muscle. Reduces hepatic secretion of VLDL. Moderately increases HDL cholesterol. PPAR-α activation is particularly effective for lowering triglycerides and is beneficial in patients with metabolic syndrome or type 2 diabetes with dyslipidemia. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Simvastatin — Incorrect: It is a statin, which works by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis. It does not act on PPAR-α. C. Ezetimibe — Incorrect: Inhibits NPC1L1 transporter in the small intestine, reducing cholesterol absorption. Has no effect on PPAR-α. D. Colestipol — Incorrect: A bile acid sequestrant that works in the intestine by binding bile acids and promoting their excretion. This indirectly reduces LDL cholesterol but has no interaction with PPAR-α.

questions.text: Drug acting on K+ channels include
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nicorandil Explanation: Nicorandil is a unique anti-anginal drug that acts via dual mechanisms: Nitrate-like action – It donates nitric oxide (NO), leading to vasodilation, especially of venous vessels. Potassium channel opener – It opens ATP-sensitive K? channels (K<sub>ATP</sub> channels) in vascular smooth muscle. This causes hyperpolarization, reducing calcium influx, leading to arteriolar vasodilation. By acting on both venous and arterial systems, nicorandil: Reduces preload (via venodilation). Reduces afterload (via arteriolar dilation). Improves coronary blood flow, helpful in angina pectoris. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Spironolactone — Incorrect: It is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. Acts on the mineralocorticoid receptor in the distal nephron, not on K? channels. B. Amiloride — Incorrect: Also a potassium-sparing diuretic, but works by blocking epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the renal collecting duct. It reduces sodium reabsorption, thereby retaining potassium, but does not directly act on K? channels. D. Methyldopa — Incorrect: It is a centrally acting alpha-2 agonist, used to treat hypertension, especially in pregnancy. It does not interact with potassium channels.

questions.text: Iv mannitol is used for the treatment of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute congestive glaucoma Explanation: Intravenous mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in emergency settings where rapid reduction in intraocular or intracranial pressure is needed. In acute congestive glaucoma, there is a sudden increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), which can threaten vision. IV mannitol: Increases plasma osmolality. Draws fluid out of the eye (aqueous humor) into the bloodstream. Rapidly reduces intraocular pressure. Thus, mannitol is particularly effective in acute angle-closure glaucoma before surgical intervention or more definitive therapy. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Pulmonary edema — Incorrect: Mannitol draws fluid into the intravascular space, which can worsen pulmonary edema due to increased preload and fluid overload. It is contraindicated in patients with heart failure or pulmonary congestion. C. Acute renal failure — Incorrect (partially): Previously used in pre-renal or early renal failure to maintain urine flow. However, it is not routinely used now because it can worsen fluid overload and has no proven benefit in established acute kidney injury. D. CHF (Congestive Heart Failure) — Incorrect: Mannitol increases plasma volume, which can exacerbate heart failure symptoms like dyspnea and edema. It is contraindicated in CHF.

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drug is avoided in patients with high serum uric acid levels?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic commonly used in the management of hypertension. However, it is known to increase serum uric acid levels by: Enhancing uric acid reabsorption in the proximal tubule. Reducing its renal excretion, leading to hyperuricemia. This can precipitate or worsen gout in susceptible individuals. Therefore, thiazide diuretics are avoided in patients with a history of gout or elevated uric acid levels. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Enalapril — Incorrect: It is an ACE inhibitor, which does not raise uric acid levels. It is actually uricosuric in some cases and safe in patients with hyperuricemia. C. Prazosin — Incorrect: An alpha-1 blocker, mainly used for hypertension and BPH. Has no significant effect on uric acid levels. D. Atenolol — Incorrect: A beta-1 selective blocker. While beta-blockers may rarely increase uric acid slightly, the effect is much less than that of thiazide diuretics. Not contraindicated in hyperuricemia.

choices.text: Continue warfarin but add Vit K

questions.text: A female patient was taking warfarin for prosthetic heart valves. She became pregnant, what advice will you give for this patient regarding use of this drug in early pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) For a pregnant patient with prosthetic heart valves who is taking warfarin, the most appropriate advice in early pregnancy is to change warfarin to heparin. Warfarin is a well-established teratogen, meaning it can cause serious birth defects, particularly when exposure occurs during the first trimester (roughly weeks 6-12) of pregnancy. These defects can include nasal hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses, and central nervous system abnormalities, collectively known as fetal warfarin syndrome. Furthermore, warfarin carries a risk of causing fetal hemorrhage at any stage of gestation due to its anticoagulant effects. Heparin, available as unfractionated heparin (UFH) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), is the anticoagulant of choice during pregnancy because it does not cross the placental barrier. This characteristic ensures that heparin provides effective thromboprophylaxis for the mother's prosthetic heart valves, thereby preventing life-threatening blood clots, without directly exposing the developing fetus to its effects and thus mitigating the risks of teratogenicity and fetal bleeding. Continuing warfarin without any concern (A) is an incorrect and dangerous recommendation due to the significant and well-documented risks of severe birth defects and hemorrhage to the fetus. Similarly, continuing warfarin but adding Vitamin K (B) is also incorrect; Vitamin K is an antidote used to reverse the anticoagulant effects of warfarin, typically in cases of bleeding or overdose, but it does not mitigate the teratogenic effects, which are independent of warfarin's anticoagulant action. Lastly, advising to terminate the pregnancy (D) is an inappropriate and unethical recommendation, as there are safe and effective medical management strategies available to allow the patient to continue her pregnancy while maintaining necessary anticoagulation.

questions.text: A patient presented to hospital with road traffic accident. This patient has raised intracranial pressure without intracranial hematoma. Which of the following drug is preferred for management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mannitol Explanation: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is commonly used to reduce intracranial pressure (ICP), especially in patients with conditions like traumatic brain injury (TBI), cerebral edema, or brain tumors, where there is elevated intracranial pressure. It works by drawing fluid out of the brain and into the bloodstream, thereby reducing the volume of cerebral edema and helping to decrease ICP. Mannitol is the drug of choice for managing elevated ICP because it not only reduces swelling but also improves cerebral perfusion. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Prednisolone — Incorrect: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that can be used to reduce inflammation in cases of brain swelling, but it is not first-line for reducing intracranial pressure. It is more commonly used for spinal cord injury or brain tumors, but not as effective as mannitol in acute traumatic brain injury with raised ICP. B. Furosemide — Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can help in reducing fluid volume, but it is not as effective as mannitol for reducing ICP. It may not have the same potent osmotically driven action that mannitol has in managing brain edema. D. Glycerol — Incorrect: Glycerol is another osmotic agent, but it is less commonly used than mannitol for controlling elevated ICP in traumatic brain injury. It has a weaker effect on reducing ICP compared to mannitol.

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of PGI2?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above Explanation: Prostacyclin (PGI2) is a prostaglandin that plays several important roles in the body. The correct answer, D — All of the above, is true because PGI2 has multiple effects, including: Inhibits platelet aggregation (A): PGI2 prevents the aggregation of platelets, which is crucial in the prevention of blood clot formation. It acts as an antiplatelet agent, opposing the effects of thromboxane A2 (TXA2), which promotes platelet aggregation. Vasodilatation (B): PGI2 causes vasodilation by relaxing the smooth muscle cells in blood vessels. This helps in reducing blood pressure and improving blood flow. Pyrogenic (C): PGI2 also has pyrogenic properties, meaning it can raise body temperature, contributing to the body's response to fever. Why the other options are incomplete: While each individual function listed (A, B, and C) is true for PGI2, D encompasses all of the effects that PGI2 has, making it the most comprehensive and correct answer.

questions.text: Analgesic drug in renal failure and patient on dialysis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Acetaminophen Explanation: In renal failure, especially in patients on dialysis, the choice of analgesic must take into account the kidney's ability to eliminate the drug and the potential for drug accumulation and toxicity. Acetaminophen (D) is the preferred analgesic in these cases because: It is primarily metabolized in the liver, and only a small amount is excreted unchanged by the kidneys. It does not typically cause further renal damage or accumulate to dangerous levels in patients with renal failure. It is considered safe for short-term use in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) or those undergoing dialysis. Why the other options are incorrect: Indomethacin (A): Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), which can worsen kidney function, especially in renal failure. NSAIDs reduce renal blood flow, potentially leading to further kidney damage. Avoid in renal failure or dialysis patients. Naproxen (B): Like indomethacin, naproxen is an NSAID that can also impair kidney function. It should be avoided in patients with renal impairment due to the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) and fluid retention. Diclofenac (C): Diclofenac is another NSAID that poses similar risks to renal function. It can cause nephrotoxicity and fluid retention, which is particularly harmful in patients with renal failure or those on dialysis.

questions.text: Drug of choice in paracetamol overdose is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) N-acetylcysteine Explanation: In paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, the primary treatment is N-acetylcysteine (NAC). Here's why: N-acetylcysteine (A) works as an antidote by replenishing glutathione, a substance in the liver that helps detoxify toxic metabolites of paracetamol. Paracetamol is metabolized in the liver to a non-toxic form but can also be metabolized to a toxic metabolite (NAPQI), which can cause severe liver damage. NAC helps to detoxify NAPQI, thus preventing liver damage and improving the prognosis of the overdose. Why the other options are incorrect: Dopamine (B): Dopamine is used in cases of shock and severe hypotension to improve blood flow to vital organs, but it has no role in paracetamol overdose. Hydralazine (C): Hydralazine is a vasodilator primarily used to treat hypertension and heart failure. It does not address the toxic effects of paracetamol overdose. Furosemide (D): Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension. It does not help with paracetamol toxicity and may even worsen renal function in overdose situations.

questions.text: A female patient was having pain in her great toe(metatarsal phalangeal ) with swelling and redness present over it. Her uric acid level high. She was treated with a proper drug therapy and her symptoms subsided. The drug that has reduced her uric acid level must act .by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Xanthine oxidase inhibitor Explanation: The patient presents with pain, swelling, and redness in the great toe, which are classic signs of gout. Gout is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals due to elevated uric acid levels in the blood (hyperuricemia). The treatment involves lowering uric acid levels to prevent further crystal formation and relieve symptoms. Xanthine oxidase inhibitors like allopurinol and febuxostat are used to reduce uric acid levels by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is responsible for the final step in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. By inhibiting this enzyme, the production of uric acid is decreased. Why the other options are incorrect: HGPRT inhibition (B): HGPRT (Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase) is an enzyme involved in purine salvage pathways. Deficiency of HGPRT leads to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, not a common treatment mechanism for gout. In gout management, reducing uric acid production is typically done through xanthine oxidase inhibition. Aldose reductase inhibitor (C): Aldose reductase inhibitors are primarily used in the management of diabetic complications like diabetic neuropathy and cataracts, not in gout or uric acid reduction. Cytochrome oxidase inhibitor (D): Cytochrome oxidase inhibitors affect mitochondrial respiration and are typically not involved in the treatment of gout or uric acid metabolism.

questions.text: A female patient was having pain in her great toe(metatarsal joint)with swelling and redness present over it, She was treated with a proper drug therapy but her uric acid still coming out to be high. Which of the following drug can be given for fast elimination of drug from he body
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Probenecid Explanation: The patient has gout, which is characterized by pain, swelling, and redness in the metatarsal joint due to the deposition of uric acid crystals. The uric acid level is high in the blood, and she is already on appropriate drug therapy for gout. The focus now is on reducing the uric acid level further. Probenecid is the correct choice because it is a uricosuric drug that increases the renal excretion of uric acid. It works by inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubules of the kidneys, thereby helping to eliminate excess uric acid more efficiently and lower the serum uric acid levels. Why the other options are incorrect: Allopurinol (A): Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used to reduce uric acid production. It is not a drug that helps to eliminate uric acid fast but instead reduces its production over time. It is useful for chronic gout management, not for rapid elimination of uric acid. Febuxostat (B): Febuxostat is another xanthine oxidase inhibitor like allopurinol, and its action is similar in reducing uric acid production. While it helps manage gout, it does not promote rapid elimination of uric acid from the body. Colchicine (C): Colchicine is used to treat acute gout attacks by reducing inflammation. It does not have a direct effect on uric acid elimination from the body. It helps with the symptoms but not with speeding up the excretion of uric acid.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. After 2 years, he developed blurring of vision and was found to have corneal opacity. Which drug is most likely to cause this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chloroquine Explanation: Chloroquine is an anti-malarial drug that is sometimes used to treat rheumatoid arthritis due to its anti-inflammatory properties. One of the known side effects of long-term chloroquine therapy is retinal toxicity, which can cause corneal opacity, blurring of vision, and other vision problems. Chloroquine can accumulate in the eye, particularly in the cornea and retina, leading to damage over time. This toxicity is often dose-related and more likely in patients who have been on long-term therapy. Why the other options are incorrect: Sulfasalazine (A): Sulfasalazine is a disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug (DMARD) used to treat rheumatoid arthritis. It can cause photosensitivity and skin reactions, but it is not commonly associated with corneal opacity or vision issues. Methotrexate (C): Methotrexate is another DMARD commonly used for rheumatoid arthritis. While it has several side effects like liver toxicity, bone marrow suppression, and gastrointestinal distress, it is not associated with corneal opacity. Vision issues are not a typical side effect of methotrexate. Leflunomide (D): Leflunomide is also a DMARD used for rheumatoid arthritis, and while it can have side effects such as liver toxicity and diarrhea, it is not linked to corneal opacity or visual disturbances.
