Give Acyclovir and wait for spontaneous vaginal delivery
Give acyclovir and do labor induction

questions.text: A pregnant female with 36 – week age of gestation have tender vesicles around vulva. Treatment done with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Give Acyclovir and plan for elective C-section Explanation: A pregnant female presenting with tender vesicles around the vulva likely has genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which can cause painful vesicular lesions. HSV infection during pregnancy presents a particular concern due to the risk of neonatal herpes, which can be severe or even fatal to the newborn. Key Points: Risk of Neonatal Herpes: If a pregnant woman has an active genital herpes outbreak at the time of delivery, there is a risk of neonatal herpes if the baby is exposed to the virus during vaginal delivery. The risk is particularly high if the mother has a primary HSV infection (i.e., the first episode during pregnancy) or if the lesions are present at the time of labor. Acyclovir: Acyclovir (or valacyclovir) is an antiviral medication used to treat herpes simplex infections. It is often administered during pregnancy to help reduce viral shedding and reduce the severity and duration of symptoms. However, while Acyclovir can help manage the infection, it does not eliminate the need for planning the mode of delivery. Elective Cesarean Section (C-Section): The best approach to prevent neonatal herpes during delivery is a cesarean section (C-section) if there are active lesions present at the time of delivery. A C-section reduces the risk of the baby coming into direct contact with the virus in the birth canal. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Give Acyclovir and wait for spontaneous vaginal delivery: While Acyclovir is useful for treating the infection, waiting for spontaneous vaginal delivery in the presence of active genital herpes (especially if the woman has primary infection or active lesions) increases the risk of neonatal herpes. C-section is the recommended delivery option in this case. C. Give Acyclovir and do labor induction: Inducing labor when there are active herpes lesions is not advised because a vaginal delivery with active lesions increases the risk of neonatal herpes. A C-section is the safer option. D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor without considering the presence of active genital herpes lesions is not appropriate, as a vaginal delivery with active lesions poses a risk to the baby. Elective C-section is the preferred management.

choices.text: OCP increase the metabolism of Rifampicin

questions.text: A women was on OCP . later she contracted TB for which she was prescribed ATT according to NTEP and she was also advised to use additional contraceptive methods. This is because
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rifampicin induces metabolism of OCPs Explanation: When a woman on oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) is prescribed anti-tuberculosis treatment (ATT), especially with Rifampicin, she is advised to use additional contraceptive methods. The reason for this is that Rifampicin, a potent enzyme inducer, increases the metabolism of OCPs, potentially reducing their effectiveness. Key Points: Rifampicin and Enzyme Induction: Rifampicin is known to induce the cytochrome P450 enzyme system in the liver, which accelerates the metabolism of various drugs, including oral contraceptives. This increased metabolism can lower the levels of OCPs in the bloodstream, potentially reducing their effectiveness and increasing the risk of unintended pregnancy. Need for Additional Contraception: Since OCPs may become less effective while the patient is on Rifampicin, the use of additional or alternative methods of contraception (e.g., condoms, IUDs) is recommended to ensure adequate contraceptive protection during treatment with Rifampicin. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Rifampicin is teratogenic: While Rifampicin can have some side effects, it is not teratogenic (i.e., it does not cause birth defects). The concern with Rifampicin in pregnancy is more about its effects on liver enzymes and potential interactions with other medications, but it is not considered teratogenic. C. Isoniazid is teratogenic: Isoniazid is not teratogenic. It is a standard drug used in the treatment of tuberculosis, and while it may have some side effects, teratogenicity is not one of them. Isoniazid is generally considered safe to use during pregnancy, although it may require careful monitoring. D. OCP increase the metabolism of Rifampicin: This is incorrect. Oral contraceptives (OCPs) do not affect the metabolism of Rifampicin. It is actually Rifampicin that increases the metabolism of OCPs, making them less effective.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used both in AIDS and Hepatitis B
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Emtricitabine Explanation: Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is commonly used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS and also has activity against Hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is included in combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) for the treatment of HIV and is also used for managing chronic hepatitis B due to its ability to inhibit the replication of HBV. Key Points: HIV/AIDS treatment: Emtricitabine is part of many first-line ART regimens for HIV because it works by inhibiting reverse transcriptase, an enzyme crucial for the replication of HIV. Hepatitis B treatment: Emtricitabine is also effective against Hepatitis B, as it inhibits the reverse transcriptase of HBV. It is often used as part of a combination regimen for chronic HBV infection. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Zidovudine: Zidovudine (AZT) is an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS, but it is not effective against Hepatitis B. It is specifically used for HIV management and has limited activity against HBV. C. Abacavir: Abacavir is another NRTI used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS, but it does not have activity against Hepatitis B. It is not a treatment option for HBV. D. Nevirapine: Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS, but it does not have activity against Hepatitis B. It specifically targets HIV and is not used for the treatment of Hepatitis B.

questions.text: Drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Voriconazole Explanation: Voriconazole is the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis, a serious fungal infection caused by the Aspergillus species, especially Aspergillus fumigatus. Voriconazole is a triazole antifungal that is highly effective against a broad spectrum of fungi, including Aspergillus, and is commonly used in the treatment of invasive aspergillosis. Key Points: Voriconazole: It has superior efficacy and safety profile compared to other antifungals for the treatment of invasive aspergillosis. It is well-absorbed orally, but intravenous administration is also available for severe cases. Voriconazole is recommended by clinical guidelines (such as those from the Infectious Diseases Society of America, IDSA) as the first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Posaconazole: Posaconazole is another triazole antifungal that has activity against Aspergillus, but it is generally used as prophylaxis (to prevent infections) in high-risk patients (e.g., hematologic malignancy patients) or in cases where voriconazole is not tolerated. It is not considered the first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis. C. Liposomal AMB (Amphotericin B): Liposomal Amphotericin B is effective against invasive fungal infections, including aspergillosis, and is often used in patients with severe or refractory infections. However, it is typically used in cases where voriconazole is contraindicated or not effective. It is considered a second-line therapy in invasive aspergillosis. D. Caspofungin: Caspofungin is an echinocandin antifungal that is effective against Candida and some molds, but it has limited activity against Aspergillus species. It is generally used for candidemia or as part of a combination therapy for invasive aspergillosis, but it is not the first-line treatment.

questions.text: A truck driver with HIV positivity develops cryptococcal meningitis. Which drug is best to start:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Liposomal Amphotericin B + 5-Flucytosine Explanation: Cryptococcal meningitis is a life-threatening fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV/AIDS and CD4 counts below 100 cells/μL. According to WHO and IDSA guidelines, the initial (induction) therapy for cryptococcal meningitis is: Liposomal Amphotericin B + 5-Flucytosine for 2 weeks This combination offers: Faster fungal clearance from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Lower mortality Reduced resistance compared to monotherapy Why the other options are incorrect: A. Liposomal Amphotericin B (monotherapy): Effective, but not optimal alone. Without 5-flucytosine, fungal clearance is slower, and outcomes are worse. B. Fluconazole: Used in the consolidation and maintenance phases after initial treatment. Not adequate as induction monotherapy—has slower onset and higher failure rate. D. 5-Flucytosine (monotherapy): Never used alone due to rapid resistance development and poor outcomes. Phases of Cryptococcal Meningitis Treatment: Induction: Liposomal Amphotericin B + 5-Flucytosine (for 2 weeks) Consolidation: Fluconazole high dose (for 8 weeks) Maintenance (secondary prophylaxis): Fluconazole low dose (until CD4 > 200 cells/μL for ≥6 months on ART)

questions.text: Mechanism of amphotericin B is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Inhibition of cell membrane synthesis Explanation: Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal that targets the fungal cell membrane, not the cell wall. Mechanism of Action: Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol, a key component of the fungal cell membrane. This binding creates pores (channels) in the membrane. As a result, ions and molecules leak out, leading to cell death. So, it disrupts the function and integrity of the cell membrane, not its synthesis per se, but the closest correct categorization is cell membrane. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Inhibition of cell wall synthesis: This is the mechanism of echinocandins (e.g., caspofungin), which inhibit β-1,3-glucan synthesis in the fungal cell wall. C. Ribosome inhibition: This is the mechanism of some antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines, aminoglycosides), not antifungals. D. Mitochondrial inhibition: Not relevant to Amphotericin B. Some antibiotics and toxins affect mitochondria, but Amphotericin B’s primary target is the cell membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes mechanism of action of azoles?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inhibit synthesis of ergosterol Explanation: Azoles (e.g., fluconazole, itraconazole, voriconazole) are a class of antifungal drugs that work by inhibiting the synthesis of ergosterol, an essential component of the fungal cell membrane. Mechanism of Action: Azoles inhibit the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme 14α-demethylase. This enzyme is crucial in the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. Without ergosterol, the fungal cell membrane becomes disrupted, leading to increased permeability and cell death or inhibition of growth. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Thymidylate synthase: This is the target of antimetabolite drugs like 5-fluorouracil (used in cancer treatment), not azoles. C. Targets beta 1,3-glucan: This is the mechanism of echinocandins (e.g., caspofungin), which inhibit β-1,3-glucan synthase, disrupting the fungal cell wall. D. Disruption of cell wall: Again, this applies to echinocandins or cell wall-targeting agents like nikkomycin, not azoles.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of oseltamivir
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Neuraminidase inhibitor Explanation: Oseltamivir (brand name: Tamiflu) is an antiviral drug used in the treatment and prevention of influenza A and B. Its primary mechanism of action is the inhibition of the neuraminidase enzyme, which is essential for viral replication and spread. Mechanism of Action: Neuraminidase is a surface enzyme on the influenza virus. It helps the newly formed viral particles to escape the host cell and spread to infect other cells. Oseltamivir inhibits neuraminidase, thereby preventing the release of new virions from infected cells. This limits the spread of infection within the respiratory tract and helps reduce the severity and duration of symptoms. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Protein synthesis inhibitor: This is the mechanism of many antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines, aminoglycosides), but not oseltamivir. B. Thymidylate synthetase inhibitor: Seen in anticancer or antiviral nucleoside analogs like 5-fluorouracil, not oseltamivir. D. Pyrimidine analogues: These are drugs like cytarabine or zidovudine, which mimic pyrimidine bases and inhibit DNA/RNA synthesis—not related to oseltamivir.

questions.text: Which one of the following antimicrobial is contraindicated in patient with seizure disorder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ciprofloxacin Explanation: Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibiotic, is contraindicated or used with caution in patients with seizure disorders because it lowers the seizure threshold and may trigger seizures, especially in predisposed individuals. Why Ciprofloxacin is contraindicated: It can inhibit GABA-A receptors in the central nervous system. GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter—when its action is blocked, neuronal excitability increases, potentially leading to seizures. The risk is higher in patients with epilepsy, renal impairment, or when taken with NSAIDs or other CNS-active drugs. Why the other options are less likely to cause seizures: A. Ampicillin: Generally safe. High doses in renal failure might cause CNS side effects, but it is not a typical seizure trigger. B. Cefixime: A third-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins can rarely cause seizures at high doses or in renal impairment, but ciprofloxacin poses a greater risk. D. Amikacin: An aminoglycoside that is more associated with ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, not seizures.

questions.text: A patient travelled to Assam. After coming back, he developed fever, chills, rigors and altered sensorium. Peripheral smear shows presence of P.falciparum. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) IV Artesunate Explanation: The patient presents with: Recent travel to Assam (a malaria-endemic region in India), Symptoms of fever, chills, rigors, and altered sensorium, Peripheral smear positive for Plasmodium falciparum. These findings suggest severe falciparum malaria, which is a medical emergency requiring parenteral therapy. Treatment of Choice for Severe Falciparum Malaria: Intravenous (IV) Artesunate is the first-line treatment for severe malaria, including cases with: Altered mental status (cerebral malaria), Renal failure, Severe anemia, Pulmonary edema, etc. IV Artesunate is recommended over quinine due to: Better efficacy, Lower mortality, Fewer side effects. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Chloroquine + Primaquine: Chloroquine is ineffective against P. falciparum in most parts of India due to widespread resistance. Primaquine is used for P. vivax relapse prevention, not in acute P. falciparum infections. B. Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine: Previously used, but now outdated due to high resistance. Not effective in severe or complicated malaria. C. Lumefantrine: Part of oral Artemisinin Combination Therapy (ACT) (e.g., Artemether + Lumefantrine). Oral ACTs are for uncomplicated malaria, not for severe or cerebral malaria.

questions.text: Mitomicin c topically useful in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Subglottic Stenosis Explanation: Mitomycin C is an antineoplastic antibiotic with antifibrotic properties, commonly used topically in ENT and ophthalmologic surgeries to prevent scar formation and restenosis. Use in Subglottic Stenosis: Subglottic stenosis is a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords, often due to prolonged intubation, trauma, or inflammation. During endoscopic or open surgical procedures to widen the stenotic airway, topical Mitomycin C is applied to: Inhibit fibroblast proliferation Reduce scar tissue formation Prevent restenosis Hence, it is topically useful in managing subglottic stenosis. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Type I Tympanoplasty: This is a surgery to repair the tympanic membrane (eardrum). Mitomycin C is not used here, as fibrosis/scarring is not a major concern. C. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis: This is a fungal infection (often seen in immunocompromised patients). Treated with antifungal drugs like Amphotericin B, not Mitomycin C. D. Post-adenoidectomy nasal bleed: Bleeding is managed with pressure, cautery, or hemostatic agents. Mitomycin C has no role in bleeding control.

questions.text: Methotrexate mechanism of action in treatment osteosarcoma is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR Explanation: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist and one of the key chemotherapeutic agents used in osteosarcoma treatment, especially in high-dose regimens. Mechanism of Action: Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). DHFR is an enzyme that converts dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF). THF is required for the synthesis of purines and thymidylate, which are essential for DNA replication. By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate blocks DNA synthesis, particularly in rapidly dividing cancer cells like those in osteosarcoma. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Analog of UMP: This describes drugs like 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), which mimic uracil monophosphate (UMP) and inhibit thymidylate synthase. C. Dihydropteroate Synthase inhibitor: This is the mechanism of sulfonamides (e.g., sulfamethoxazole), which are antibacterials, not anticancer drugs. D. Pyrimidine analogue: Pyrimidine analogues include drugs like cytarabine or 5-FU. Methotrexate is a folate analogue, not a pyrimidine analogue. Clinical Insight: High-dose methotrexate is a backbone of osteosarcoma chemotherapy. It is often followed by leucovorin (folinic acid) rescue to protect normal cells from toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act by breaking the double strand of DNA ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cyclophosphamide Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent (a nitrogen mustard derivative) used in cancer chemotherapy. Its cytotoxic effect comes from its ability to damage DNA, particularly by forming cross-links. Mechanism of Action of Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide gets activated in the liver to form phosphoramide mustard, which then: Alkylates DNA at the N7 position of guanine. Causes inter- and intra-strand cross-linking of DNA. This disrupts DNA replication and transcription, ultimately causing double-strand breaks and cell death. Thus, it damages DNA by cross-linking and indirectly leads to double-strand breaks, especially during DNA replication. Why the other options are incorrect: A. 6-Mercaptopurine: A purine analogue that inhibits de novo purine synthesis. It interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis but does not break DNA strands. B. Actinomycin D: Intercalates between DNA base pairs and inhibits RNA polymerase, blocking transcription. It does not directly break DNA strands. C. Mitomycin C: Functions as a bioreductive alkylating agent. It cross-links DNA, especially under hypoxic conditions, but is less associated with direct strand breaks than cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: Basiliximab mechanism of action is on-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IL-2 Explanation: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody used primarily as an immunosuppressant in organ transplantation, especially renal transplants, to prevent acute rejection. Mechanism of Action: Basiliximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to the IL-2 receptor α-chain (CD25) on the surface of activated T cells. By binding to CD25, it blocks interleukin-2 (IL-2) from binding to its receptor. This prevents T-cell proliferation, a key step in initiating graft rejection. So, it targets the IL-2 receptor, not IL-2 directly, but since its effect is to block IL-2 signaling, Option A: IL-2 is the best answer. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Epidermal Growth Factor: Targeted by drugs like cetuximab or erlotinib, used in cancer therapy, not immunosuppression. C. IL-1: Targeted by anakinra, used in autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis. D. CD11: Involved in leukocyte adhesion. Drugs like efalizumab target CD11a, but not used in transplant immunosuppression.

questions.text: Tocilizumab works against
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) IL-6 Explanation: Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody used as an immunosuppressive agent. It specifically targets and inhibits IL-6, a cytokine involved in immune response and inflammation. Mechanism of Action of Tocilizumab: Tocilizumab binds to the IL-6 receptor (IL-6R), blocking IL-6 from binding to its receptor on target cells. IL-6 is a key mediator in the inflammatory response and plays a role in several autoimmune diseases and conditions. By inhibiting IL-6 signaling, tocilizumab is used in the treatment of diseases like: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (SJIA) Cytokine release syndrome (CRS) associated with certain treatments like CAR T-cell therapy. Why the other options are incorrect: A. IL-2: Targeted by basiliximab and daclizumab (both used in immunosuppressive therapy), not tocilizumab. B. IL-1: Targeted by anakinra (used for conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and autoinflammatory diseases), not tocilizumab. D. IL-8: Involved in neutrophil recruitment, but not specifically targeted by tocilizumab. Summary: Tocilizumab: Monoclonal antibody that inhibits the IL-6 receptor. Used in: Rheumatoid arthritis, Cytokine release syndrome, and Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with breathlessness, dry cough with reduced exercise capacity. On X ray examination , diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis is made. Which of the following drug can be used for the treatment of this condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pirfenidone Explanation: Pirfenidone is an antifibrotic agent that is used to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a type of pulmonary fibrosis. Mechanism of Action of Pirfenidone: Pirfenidone has anti-inflammatory and antifibrotic properties. It works by: Inhibiting fibroblast proliferation and collagen production. Reducing fibrosis in the lungs and slowing the progression of pulmonary fibrosis. This helps in improving lung function and slowing the decline in exercise capacity in patients with IPF. It is FDA-approved for the treatment of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and is commonly used in clinical practice to slow disease progression. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Roflumilast: Roflumilast is a phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE4) inhibitor primarily used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is not effective in treating pulmonary fibrosis. C. Doxapram: Doxapram is a respiratory stimulant used in conditions like acute respiratory failure and is not effective in treating pulmonary fibrosis. D. Imatinib: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of certain cancers like chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). While it has been shown to have some effects in fibrosis, it is not the first-line treatment for pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 68 year old male cancer patient on chemotherapy developed neutropenja. Which of the following drug is used to increase the immunity in this person?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Filgrastim Explanation: Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) used to stimulate the production of neutrophils. It is commonly used in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy who develop neutropenia (low neutrophil count), which increases the risk of infections. Mechanism of Action of Filgrastim: Filgrastim is a recombinant form of G-CSF that stimulates the bone marrow to produce more neutrophils. It helps reduce the risk of infection by increasing the number of neutrophils, which are key components of the immune system involved in fighting bacterial infections. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Darbepoetin: Darbepoetin is an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) used to treat anemia (low red blood cells) in conditions like chronic kidney disease or chemotherapy, but it does not affect neutrophil production. C. Oprelvekin: Oprelvekin is a recombinant interleukin-11 (IL-11) that stimulates platelet production in patients with thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), not neutrophils. D. Iron dextran: Iron dextran is used to treat iron deficiency anemia by replenishing iron stores but does not influence neutrophil count or immunity.

questions.text: Anti-glaucoma drug that acts by increasing uveoscleraloutlfow is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Latanoprost Explanation: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue that is commonly used to treat glaucoma and ocular hypertension. It works by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, which helps to lower intraocular pressure (IOP). Mechanism of Action of Latanoprost: Latanoprost acts by stimulating the prostanoid FP receptors in the eye. This leads to increased uveoscleral outflow, which is one of the pathways through which aqueous humor drains from the eye. By enhancing the outflow of aqueous humor, latanoprost lowers intraocular pressure (IOP), which is crucial in the management of glaucoma. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that decreases the production of aqueous humor, not by increasing outflow. It works by reducing the formation of fluid in the eye. C. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist that works by increasing trabecular outflow, not uveoscleral outflow. It also contracts the ciliary muscle, improving the drainage of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork. D. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces the production of aqueous humor, lowering intraocular pressure, but it does not affect the outflow pathways directly.

questions.text: Which of the following drug will be used for OAG in this patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Latanoprost Explanation: The question refers to open-angle glaucoma (OAG), a condition where increased intraocular pressure (IOP) causes damage to the optic nerve. Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, is commonly used to treat OAG. Mechanism of Action of Latanoprost: Latanoprost works by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, a pathway for fluid drainage in the eye. By enhancing this outflow, latanoprost effectively lowers intraocular pressure (IOP), which is key in managing open-angle glaucoma and preventing damage to the optic nerve. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Carboprost: Carboprost is a prostaglandin analogue used in obstetrics to treat postpartum hemorrhage and induce labor. It is not used for glaucoma. C. Alprostadil: Alprostadil is a prostaglandin E1 analogue used to treat erectile dysfunction and maintain patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates. It is not used for glaucoma. D. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is also a prostaglandin analogue but is used in obstetrics for inducing abortion or labor. It is not used for managing glaucoma. Summary: Latanoprost is a first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma as it reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor via the uveoscleral pathway.

questions.text: An 11 year old boy presented to emergency with vomiting. Parents gave history of consuming 8 tablets of ferrous sulphate. What is the antidote of iron for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Desferrioxamine Explanation: Iron poisoning is a serious medical emergency, especially in children, and commonly results from accidental ingestion of iron tablets (like ferrous sulfate). Toxic doses can cause gastrointestinal symptoms, metabolic acidosis, shock, hepatic failure, and even death. Antidote: Desferrioxamine Desferrioxamine (Deferoxamine) is the specific antidote for iron poisoning. It is a chelating agent that binds free iron in the bloodstream, forming a complex called ferrioxamine, which is excreted in the urine. It helps prevent iron-induced oxidative damage and systemic toxicity. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Dimercaprol (BAL): Used for arsenic, mercury, and lead poisoning, not iron. C. D-Penicillamine: Chelates copper and is used in Wilson’s disease and rheumatoid arthritis, but not for acute iron poisoning. D. Succimer (DMSA): An oral chelating agent used for lead and some heavy metal poisonings, not effective for iron.

questions.text: DOC for smoking cessation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Varenicline Explanation: Varenicline is the drug of choice (DOC) for smoking cessation due to its high efficacy in reducing nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms. Mechanism of Action of Varenicline: Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the brain. It works in two ways: Reduces cravings by providing mild stimulation of the receptor. Blocks nicotine from binding if the person smokes, thereby reducing the rewarding effects of smoking. This dual action makes it more effective than many other options, especially for individuals committed to quitting smoking. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Acamprosate: Used in alcohol dependence to maintain abstinence. Not useful for nicotine addiction. C. Thalidomide: An immunomodulatory drug used for multiple myeloma and erythema nodosum leprosum. It has no role in smoking cessation. D. Tryptophan: An amino acid precursor to serotonin; not used for smoking cessation.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clotrimazole Explanation: The patient is likely suffering from oral candidiasis (oral thrush), which is a common side effect in bronchial asthma patients using inhaled corticosteroids. Steroids can suppress local immunity in the oral cavity, making it easier for Candida species to overgrow. Treatment: Clotrimazole is a topical antifungal agent commonly used as a troche (lozenge) for local treatment of oral candidiasis. It is effective against Candida albicans, the usual causative organism. Other options: Griseofulvin: Effective against dermatophytes, not Candida. Not useful in oral candidiasis. Terbinafine: Also mainly active against dermatophytes, not Candida. Flucytosine: Used for systemic Candida or Cryptococcus infections, usually in serious invasive cases (often with amphotericin B), not for localized oral thrush.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with history of bronchial asthma is in the third stage of labour. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this mother?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Carboprost Explanation: In the management of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), uterotonic agents are used to contract the uterus and reduce bleeding. However, drug choice must consider patient-specific contraindications, such as bronchial asthma. Carboprost (15-methyl PGF2α): It is a prostaglandin F2α analogue. While effective in controlling PPH, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction, which may trigger a life-threatening asthma attack. Other options: Oxytocin: First-line agent in PPH; safe in asthma. Dinoprostone (PGE2 analogue): Can be used cautiously, though it may have mild bronchoconstrictive effects, it is generally considered safer than PGF2α analogues. Methyl ergometrine: Contraindicated in hypertension, not asthma (use cautiously if coexisting conditions exist, but not absolutely contraindicated in asthma).

questions.text: Name the drug that inhibits both Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) and neural endopeptidase?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Omapatrilat Explanation: Omapatrilat is a drug that inhibits both: Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) – which converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor. Neutral endopeptidase (also called neprilysin) – which breaks down natriuretic peptides like ANP and BNP that promote vasodilation and natriuresis. Clinical Significance: By inhibiting both enzymes, omapatrilat offers dual action: reducing vasoconstriction and enhancing vasodilation. It was developed for use in heart failure and hypertension. However, it was withdrawn from development due to a higher incidence of angioedema, likely because both ACE and neprilysin break down bradykinin — leading to its accumulation when both are inhibited. Other options: A. Sacubitril: Inhibits neprilysin only. Often combined with valsartan (an ARB) in heart failure treatment. B. Losartan: An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB); does not inhibit ACE or neprilysin. C. Nesiritide: A recombinant B-type natriuretic peptide, used in acute decompensated heart failure; it mimics but does not inhibit neprilysin or ACE.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these side effects?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amiodarone Explanation: Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug commonly used for ventricular arrhythmias and atrial fibrillation. While it is effective, it has a notoriously long list of adverse effects due to its high iodine content and tendency to accumulate in tissues. Key Side Effects of Amiodarone: Pulmonary toxicity: Can cause pulmonary fibrosis, a serious and potentially fatal side effect. Thyroid dysfunction: Both hypo- and hyperthyroidism. Hepatotoxicity Skin changes: Photosensitivity, blue-gray skin discoloration. Neurologic symptoms: Tremor, ataxia, neuropathy. Ocular toxicity Cardiovascular effects: Bradycardia and hypotension. Patient Clues Matching Amiodarone Toxicity: Fatigue, dyspnea, weight gain: Can indicate hypothyroidism or heart failure worsening. Pulmonary fibrosis: Classic and serious complication of long-term amiodarone therapy. History of MI and ventricular arrhythmia: Typical indication for starting amiodarone. Why Not the Others? Atenolol: Beta-blocker; may cause fatigue and bradycardia, but not pulmonary fibrosis. Aspirin: Can cause GI bleeding or asthma exacerbation, not pulmonary fibrosis. Spironolactone: Can cause gynecomastia and hyperkalemia, not pulmonary fibrosis.

Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after consuming 100 tablets of Aspirin. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sodium bicarbonate to alkalize the urine Explanation: The patient has likely experienced a salicylate (aspirin) overdose, which is a medical emergency. High doses of aspirin can lead to: Metabolic acidosis (with increased anion gap) Respiratory alkalosis (initially due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center) Tinnitus, nausea, vomiting, confusion, and even coma in severe toxicity Management of Aspirin Overdose: The primary goals are to: Reduce salicylate absorption Enhance salicylate elimination Correct acid-base and fluid-electrolyte disturbances Key intervention: Sodium bicarbonate: This is used to alkalinize the urine, which increases the ionized form of salicylate, reducing its reabsorption in the renal tubules and enhancing its excretion. Urinary alkalinization is the cornerstone of treatment in moderate to severe salicylate poisoning. Why not the others? A. N-acetylcysteine: Used for paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, not salicylates. B. Pralidoxime: Antidote for organophosphate poisoning, not aspirin. C. Glucagon: Used in beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker overdose, not aspirin.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking deaddiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rebound hypertension Explanation: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in smoking cessation to help reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms. It works by inhibiting sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system, leading to decreased blood pressure and reduced symptoms of withdrawal. However, abrupt discontinuation of clonidine can lead to a rebound increase in sympathetic tone. This can cause: Rebound hypertension: A sudden increase in blood pressure due to the loss of the inhibitory effect of clonidine on sympathetic nervous activity. Headache: A common symptom associated with rebound hypertension. The mechanism behind rebound hypertension is the upregulation of alpha-1 receptors due to chronic clonidine use, and without the drug, the increased sympathetic activity causes a surge in blood pressure. Why not the others? A. Postural hypotension: Clonidine can cause hypotension when first started or in excessive doses, but rebound hypertension is more likely after discontinuation. B. Receptor upregulation: While upregulation of receptors can occur with chronic clonidine use, the main issue after stopping the drug is rebound hypertension, not upregulation alone. D. Receptor hypersensitivity: This term is more commonly used in reference to other conditions (e.g., beta-receptor hypersensitivity in asthma), but it’s not the best description of what occurs after stopping clonidine.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent attacks of gout was started on a therapy that inhibits the synthesis of uric acid. His symptoms were reduced after therapy. Which drug was he started on?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Allopurinol Explanation: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is involved in the conversion of purines to uric acid. It is the first-line therapy for chronic gout and is used to prevent recurrent gout attacks by lowering serum uric acid levels. In gout, recurrent attacks occur due to elevated uric acid levels in the blood, which can crystallize and deposit in joints, causing inflammation. By inhibiting uric acid synthesis, allopurinol helps to prevent these attacks. Why not the others? A. Probenecid: This is a uricosuric agent that increases the excretion of uric acid by the kidneys, rather than inhibiting its production. It is used to manage gout in some cases but is not the drug of choice for reducing uric acid synthesis. B. Colchicine: Colchicine is used to treat acute gout attacks by reducing inflammation. However, it does not lower uric acid levels or prevent recurrent attacks long-term. D. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to reduce the inflammation and pain associated with acute gout attacks, but it does not affect uric acid production or prevent recurrent attacks.

questions.text: A patient with malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy. The platelet counts were reduced after the previous cycle of chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oprelvekin (IL-11) Explanation: Oprelvekin is an interleukin-11 (IL-11) analog that is used to stimulate platelet production in patients with chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia (low platelet count). Chemotherapy can lead to bone marrow suppression, reducing platelet production and increasing the risk of bleeding. Oprelvekin helps by promoting megakaryocyte development, which leads to increased platelet counts. Why not the others? B. Filgrastim: Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that stimulates the production of neutrophils (not platelets). It is used in cases of neutropenia (low white blood cell count), often after chemotherapy, but it does not address platelet deficiency. C. Erythropoietin: Erythropoietin stimulates the production of red blood cells (RBCs), not platelets. It is used in conditions like anemia, particularly in chronic kidney disease or chemotherapy-induced anemia, but not for thrombocytopenia. D. Amifostine: Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent used to reduce the toxic effects of chemotherapy, particularly for kidney protection in certain chemotherapy regimens, but it does not directly increase platelet production.

The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.

questions.text: The true statement among the following is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation Explanation: Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) commonly used to treat hypertension and heart failure. In addition to its primary effect of blocking the angiotensin II receptor (AT1), it has also been shown to have a secondary effect as a thromboxane A2 antagonist. Thromboxane A2 promotes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction, so by inhibiting this, losartan can reduce platelet aggregation, which might help in reducing the risk of thrombotic events. Why not the others? A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure: This is incorrect. Telmisartan, like other ARBs, requires dose adjustment in renal failure but does not typically require dose reduction in hepatic failure unless the patient has severe liver impairment. B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure: This is incorrect. Irbesartan requires dose adjustment mainly in cases of severe renal failure. There is no need to reduce the dose in mild to moderate hepatic impairment unless there is severe hepatic dysfunction. C. The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure: This is incorrect. Candesartan should be adjusted in renal failure, especially in cases of severe renal dysfunction. It does not typically require dose adjustment in mild-moderate hepatic failure.

questions.text: A patient given digoxin started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4mg/dl. The plasma therapeutic range is 1mg/dl. If the half life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long should one wait before resuming the treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 80 hours Explanation: When a patient develops symptoms of digoxin toxicity (such as nausea and vomiting), the first step is to stop the medication. Digoxin has a long half-life (40 hours in this case), meaning it takes a long time for the drug to be eliminated from the body. The goal is to wait until the serum concentration of digoxin falls within the therapeutic range. Key Points: Therapeutic range of digoxin: 1 mg/dl. Current serum concentration: 4 mg/dl. Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours. The general formula to estimate the time it will take for a drug to decrease to a safe concentration is: Time to reach therapeutic level = Half-life × log 2 ( Current concentration Therapeutic concentration) Time to reach therapeutic level=Half-life×log 2 ( Therapeutic concentration Current concentration ) However, a simplified approach is to wait around 5 half-lives for a drug to drop close to a therapeutic range (for many drugs). This is because after 5 half-lives, the concentration typically falls by over 95%. Calculation: Given: Half-life of digoxin = 40 hours You would wait approximately 5 half-lives. 5 × 40 = 200 hours 5×40=200 hours However, this calculation suggests an extended period. For clinical practicality and rapid therapeutic adjustment, a closer approximation is usually 2 half-lives for initial symptom resolution and then reassessment. Hence, 80 hours (which is 2 half-lives) is a reasonable estimate for when to reconsider therapy. Why not the others? A. 40 hours: This would only cover one half-life, not enough time for digoxin to reach therapeutic levels. C. 120 hours: While longer than necessary, this is an overestimate and unnecessary for most patients. D. 140-180 hours: This is far too long and does not fit typical clinical guidelines for drug elimination.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Atropine toxicity Explanation: Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist commonly used to treat organophosphate poisoning, as it blocks the effects of excess acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. However, atropine can have side effects, especially when given in large doses or as an infusion. One of the known side effects of atropine is hyperthermia (fever). This can occur because: Atropine reduces sweating (by inhibiting the parasympathetic nervous system), which leads to impaired heat dissipation. It can also cause central nervous system effects, including altered thermoregulation. In cases of organophosphate poisoning, atropine is given to counteract the muscarinic effects of the poisoning, but if too much atropine is used, toxic effects can result, including fever, dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention. Why not the others? B. Side effect of pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase and reverse the effects of organophosphate poisoning. It generally does not cause a significant rise in temperature. C. Due to organophosphate poisoning: While organophosphates can cause muscarinic effects like excessive salivation, bronchorrhea, and bradycardia, fever is more commonly due to atropine toxicity rather than the poisoning itself. Organophosphate poisoning leads to hypothermia in some cases due to excessive cholinergic stimulation, rather than fever. D. Idiopathic: While fever can sometimes occur without a clear cause, in this case, the administration of atropine strongly suggests that the fever is likely due to atropine toxicity.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Enhance fibrin degradation Explanation: Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is a thrombolytic agent used to treat conditions like acute ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, and pulmonary embolism by promoting the breakdown of fibrin in blood clots. The mechanism of action of tPA involves the conversion of plasminogen (which is incorporated into clots) into plasmin, the enzyme that degrades fibrin, breaking down the clot. Thus, tPA enhances fibrin degradation, leading to the dissolution of thrombi. Why not the others? A. Inhibits extrinsic pathway: The extrinsic pathway of coagulation involves tissue factor and factor VII, which initiates clotting. tPA does not directly inhibit the extrinsic pathway but works by promoting fibrinolysis (clot breakdown). B. Inhibits platelet aggregation: While antiplatelet drugs like aspirin or clopidogrel inhibit platelet aggregation, tPA does not work by inhibiting platelet aggregation. Its action is centered around fibrinolysis. D. Inhibit clot formation: tPA does not inhibit clot formation; instead, it promotes the breakdown of clots after they have formed.

questions.text: IV Loading dose of drug is dependent on
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Volume of distribution Explanation: The IV loading dose of a drug is calculated to rapidly achieve a therapeutic plasma concentration of the drug. The formula for the loading dose is typically: Loading Dose = Desired Plasma Concentration × Volume of Distribution (Vd) Bioavailability (F) Loading Dose= Bioavailability (F) Desired Plasma Concentration×Volume of Distribution (Vd) ? Volume of distribution (Vd) is a key factor in determining the loading dose. It reflects the extent to which a drug distributes in body tissues and fluids. A larger Vd means the drug distributes more widely in the body, requiring a higher loading dose to achieve the desired plasma concentration. Why not the others? A. Clearance: While clearance is important for determining maintenance doses (to replace the amount of drug being eliminated), it is not directly involved in calculating the loading dose. B. Route of administration: The route of administration affects the bioavailability of the drug, but the loading dose calculation primarily depends on the volume of distribution, not the route. For IV administration, bioavailability is 100%, meaning it's already fully absorbed. D. Bioavailability: While bioavailability affects how much of the drug reaches the systemic circulation, the loading dose formula incorporates it as part of the calculation. In the case of IV administration, bioavailability is assumed to be 100%, so it doesn't impact the dose calculation significantly.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Competitive Explanation: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This type of inhibition affects the apparent affinity (Km) for the substrate but does not affect the maximum velocity (Vmax). Graphically, in a competitive inhibition scenario, the Km increases (shift to the right in the Michaelis-Menten curve), meaning that a higher concentration of substrate is needed to reach the same reaction rate. However, Vmax remains unchanged because, at very high substrate concentrations, the substrate can outcompete the inhibitor. Key Characteristics of Competitive Inhibition: Vmax: Unchanged. Km: Increased (rightward shift). The inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site. Why not the others? B. Non-competitive inhibition: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to a site other than the active site (allosteric site). It lowers the Vmax and does not affect Km. C. Un-competitive inhibition: In un-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, and both Vmax and Km decrease. D. Allosteric inhibition: Allosteric inhibition involves binding at an allosteric site (not the active site), leading to conformational changes in the enzyme. It can cause changes in both Km and Vmax, but this is typically not represented by the graph shown in competitive inhibition.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials is drug dosing is determined?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Phase -1 Explanation: Phase 1 clinical trials are the first stage of testing a new drug in humans. The primary goal of Phase 1 trials is to determine the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of the drug. This phase also involves determining the appropriate drug dosage (starting with a low dose and gradually increasing it) and identifying any side effects or toxicities that may occur. In Phase 1: Drug dosing is determined by monitoring the effects at various dose levels. The study usually involves a small group of healthy volunteers. This phase provides critical data to guide dosing in subsequent phases of clinical trials (Phase 2 and Phase 3). Why not the others? B. Phase 2: Phase 2 trials focus on evaluating the efficacy of the drug and determining its side effects in a larger group of patients. While some adjustments to dosing may occur, the primary goal here is to assess therapeutic outcomes, not dosing. C. Phase 3: Phase 3 trials involve large-scale testing to confirm the drug's effectiveness and monitor side effects in a diverse patient population. By this stage, dosing should already be determined, and the focus shifts to comparative efficacy and safety. D. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug has been approved and is on the market. These are typically post-marketing surveillance studies that gather information about long-term effects and rare side effects but do not involve determining drug dosing.

questions.text: A patient is found on a railway track with hot dry skin, raised temperature, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dhatura poisoning Explanation: Dhatura poisoning (or Datura poisoning) is caused by ingestion of plants from the Solanaceae family, such as Datura stramonium. These plants contain tropane alkaloids like atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which have anticholinergic effects. Key symptoms of Datura poisoning: Hot, dry skin: due to impaired sweating (anticholinergic effect). Raised temperature (fever): due to lack of sweating and impaired thermoregulation. Dilated pupils (mydriasis): common in anticholinergic poisoning. Slurred speech: another manifestation of anticholinergic toxicity. Staggering gait: indicative of CNS effects like confusion and ataxia. Why not the others? B. Alcohol intoxication: Alcohol intoxication can cause slurred speech, staggering gait, and altered mental status. However, it typically does not cause hot dry skin, raised temperature, or dilated pupils. These symptoms are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity like that caused by Datura poisoning. C. Opioid overdose: Opioid overdose presents with pinpoint pupils, respiratory depression, and CNS depression. It does not typically cause hot dry skin, dilated pupils, or a raised temperature. D. Cocaine poisoning: Cocaine toxicity can cause sympathomimetic effects such as increased heart rate, hypertension, agitation, and dilated pupils, but it does not typically cause hot dry skin or slurred speech in the way that anticholinergic toxicity does.

questions.text: A 30-year-old drug addict presents to the emergency department with signs of unknown drug poisoning. The patient exhibits dilated pupils, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tremors. On examination. the blood pressure is l60/100 mmHg, and the heart rate is 120 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cocaine intoxication Explanation: The symptoms presented—dilated pupils, diaphoresis (sweating), tachycardia, tremors, and elevated blood pressure (160/100 mmHg)—are characteristic of sympathomimetic drug toxicity, which is commonly associated with cocaine intoxication. Cocaine is a stimulant that increases the release of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin in the brain, leading to: Dilated pupils (mydriasis), which is a common effect of sympathomimetic drugs. Tachycardia (elevated heart rate) and increased blood pressure due to sympathetic stimulation. Diaphoresis (profuse sweating) as part of the adrenergic response. Tremors and other signs of CNS overstimulation (e.g., agitation or restlessness). Why not the others? B. Morphine poisoning: Morphine is an opioid, and its poisoning typically leads to CNS depression, respiratory depression, miosis (pinpoint pupils), and bradycardia, not the sympathomimetic signs seen here (e.g., dilated pupils, tachycardia, diaphoresis). C. Chlorpheniramine poisoning: Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine that has some anticholinergic effects, such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and dilated pupils. However, it would not typically cause tachycardia, diaphoresis, or tremors to the extent seen with cocaine intoxication. D. Alcohol intoxication: Alcohol intoxication generally causes CNS depression, slurred speech, ataxia, and hypoventilation. It does not cause the sympathomimetic effects like diaphoresis, tachycardia, and dilated pupils seen in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bisoprolol Explanation: Bisoprolol is a beta-blocker that has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF). It is a cardioselective beta-1 antagonist that helps in reducing the heart's workload and improving cardiac function, which is beneficial in heart failure management. Key Points: Bisoprolol has been shown to improve survival and reduce hospitalizations in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The MERIT-HF trial demonstrated that bisoprolol improves survival rates and reduces the risk of death and hospitalization in heart failure patients. Why not the others? A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker, and while beta-blockers, in general, can help in heart failure, propranolol is not as commonly used in heart failure management due to its non-selectivity and the availability of more effective agents like bisoprolol. C. Labetalol: Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker and alpha-1 antagonist. It is mainly used for hypertension and acute management of hypertensive crises, not specifically for reducing mortality in congestive heart failure. D. Pindolol: Pindolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (partial agonist activity). It is not commonly used in the treatment of congestive heart failure as it may not be as effective in improving outcomes compared to other beta-blockers like bisoprolol.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is appropriate for treating a 75-yearold woman a known Alzheimer’s with memory difficulty having urinary incontinence triggered by stress, such as coughing?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tolterodine Explanation: The patient in question is a 75-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease who is experiencing urinary incontinence triggered by stress, such as coughing. This suggests urge incontinence, which can often occur in patients with Alzheimer's disease due to overactive bladder muscles. Tolterodine is an antimuscarinic agent used primarily for the treatment of overactive bladder and urinary incontinence, including urgency and stress incontinence. It works by inhibiting muscarinic receptors in the bladder, reducing bladder contractions and helping to control urinary incontinence. Why not the others? A. Ipratropium: Ipratropium is an anticholinergic used mainly for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. It works by dilating the bronchi in the lungs and does not have a role in managing urinary incontinence. C. Telenzepine: Telenzepine is a selective M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and gastric issues, not for managing urinary incontinence. D. Tropicamide: Tropicamide is an anticholinergic used primarily for pupil dilation during eye exams and does not have any relevance to treating urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient stopped antihypertensive medication due to dry eyes, mouth and constipation. After stoppage of drug he developed hypertensive emergency (BP> 180/120). Most likely drug is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clonidine Explanation: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It works by stimulating receptors in the brain that reduce sympathetic nervous system activity, leading to decreased blood pressure. However, clonidine has a well-known issue: when discontinued suddenly, it can lead to a rebound hypertensive crisis (hypertensive emergency) due to a sudden increase in sympathetic tone. Key symptoms of clonidine withdrawal: Dry mouth Dry eyes Constipation Hypertensive emergency (BP > 180/120 mmHg) upon abrupt discontinuation This happens because the body, after being accustomed to clonidine's effects, suddenly experiences an excessive release of norepinephrine, leading to significant vasoconstriction and a sharp rise in blood pressure. Why not the others? B. Lisinopril: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, and stopping it would not cause a rebound hypertensive crisis. ACE inhibitors do not have the same withdrawal effects as clonidine. Stopping lisinopril might lead to elevated blood pressure over time, but not as abruptly or severely as clonidine. C. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension. Stopping amlodipine typically causes a gradual return of elevated blood pressure, but it does not lead to the acute rebound hypertensive crisis seen with clonidine. D. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker. Sudden withdrawal of beta-blockers can cause a rebound tachycardia and increased blood pressure, but it is less likely to cause the severe hypertensive emergency seen with clonidine. It may also cause symptoms like tachycardia, but not the same rapid hypertensive spike as clonidine.

questions.text: A patient with normal renal function requires reversal muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sugammadex Explanation: Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent that is used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium. It works by binding to vecuronium (and other similar agents like rocuronium), forming a complex that prevents the drug from binding to the nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing muscle relaxation. Sugammadex is a highly effective and rapid way to reverse the effects of vecuronium and other steroidal non-depolarizing agents. Why not the others? A. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to reverse anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., atropine poisoning) and not typically used for reversing muscle relaxants like vecuronium. It works by increasing acetylcholine levels, but it's not effective in the context of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. B. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, commonly used to treat Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease dementia. Like physostigmine, it does not reverse the effects of vecuronium and is not suitable for muscle relaxation reversal. D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant, not a reversal agent. It works by depolarizing the neuromuscular junction, leading to temporary muscle paralysis. It would not reverse the effects of vecuronium and could worsen the situation.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Excessive use can result in methemoglobinemia Explanation: EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics) is a topical anesthetic cream commonly used to numb the skin before procedures like needle insertions. It contains two local anesthetics: lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine in a 1:1 ratio. Excessive use or inappropriate application of EMLA can lead to methemoglobinemia, a condition where the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized, reducing the blood's ability to carry oxygen. This risk is particularly higher in infants, individuals with G6PD deficiency, or those who use EMLA on large surface areas for prolonged periods. Why not the others? A. It is Equal Mixture of Local Anaesthetics: While EMLA is a mixture of local anesthetics, the correct combination is lidocaine and prilocaine in a 1:1 ratio, not other combinations like lidocaine and ropivacaine. B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine in a ratio of 50 percent: This statement is incorrect because EMLA contains lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine, not ropivacaine. The ratio is also not specifically 50 percent, but a 1:1 ratio of lidocaine and prilocaine.

questions.text: A middle aged patient suffering from headache and blurring of vision while watching a movie having mid dilated pupil. What is the drug to be used for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mannitol + pilocarpine Explanation: The symptoms described in the question—headache, blurring of vision, and a mid-dilated pupil—are indicative of acute angle-closure glaucoma. This is a medical emergency that occurs when the drainage angle in the eye becomes blocked, leading to a sudden increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). Management: Mannitol: This is an osmotic diuretic that helps lower intraocular pressure (IOP) by drawing fluid out of the eye. Pilocarpine: This is a miotic agent (a drug that constricts the pupil). It helps relieve the blockage in the drainage angle by constricting the pupil, thus allowing better drainage of aqueous humor and reducing IOP. This combination of mannitol and pilocarpine is typically used in acute angle-closure glaucoma to rapidly lower IOP and alleviate symptoms. Why not the others? A. Mannitol + atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic that causes pupil dilation, which would worsen the situation in angle-closure glaucoma, where constricting the pupil is needed to open the angle and allow drainage. C. Mannitol + moxifloxacin: Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic and has no role in managing acute angle-closure glaucoma. It does not address the underlying issue of elevated IOP. D. Mannitol + carboxymethyl cellulose: Carboxymethyl cellulose is a lubricating agent used for dry eyes and does not affect intraocular pressure or the underlying issue in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness. The child has no significant medical history. On examination, the heart rate is 220 beats per minute, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and the child appears anxious but is otherwise stable. An ECG confirms the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).What is the initial recommended dose of adenosine for this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 0.1 mg/kg Explanation: Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT) is a common arrhythmia in children, often presenting with symptoms like palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness, as seen in this case. The treatment of choice for PSVT in the emergency setting is adenosine. Adenosine works by blocking the AV node, which temporarily halts conduction and can break the arrhythmia. Initial Dose of Adenosine: The initial dose for children is 0.1 mg/kg as a rapid intravenous (IV) push. If the first dose does not successfully terminate the arrhythmia, the dose can be doubled for subsequent attempts (i.e., 0.2 mg/kg and then 0.5 mg/kg if necessary). Why not the others? B. 0.2 mg/kg: This is the correct dose for a second attempt if the initial dose of 0.1 mg/kg does not work. C. 0.5 mg/kg: This is the dose for a third attempt, usually when the first two doses fail. D. 1.0 mg/kg: This is not a recommended initial dose. Doses higher than 0.2 mg/kg are generally not used initially due to the risk of side effects.

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is recommended for a pregnant female at 30 weeks of gestation who develops deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with calf tenderness and diagnosed via Doppler ultrasound?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) Explanation: For a pregnant female at 30 weeks of gestation who develops deep vein thrombosis (DVT), the recommended anticoagulant is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). LMWH is preferred during pregnancy because it does not cross the placenta, making it safe for the fetus. It is also effective in preventing further thrombus formation and in treating established DVT. Why not the others? A. Warfarin: Warfarin is contraindicated during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester and later in pregnancy because it can cross the placenta and cause fetal harm, including bleeding and craniofacial abnormalities. C. Apixaban: Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) and is generally avoided in pregnancy due to limited safety data and its potential to cross the placenta, which could harm the fetus. D. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is a factor Xa inhibitor and while it does not cross the placenta, it is not the first-line treatment in pregnancy for DVT. LMWH is usually preferred as it has more established safety and efficacy data in pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 37 weeks of gestation, currently on warfarin for a prosthetic valve, comes for a routine antenatal checkup. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Switch to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) Explanation: In a pregnant female with a prosthetic valve who is currently on warfarin, the appropriate management involves switching to Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) as soon as possible during pregnancy. Warfarin is contraindicated during pregnancy, especially during the first trimester and third trimester, because it crosses the placenta and can cause fetal harm, such as embryopathy, bleeding, or craniofacial abnormalities. Therefore, it is critical to switch to a safe alternative like LMWH for the remainder of the pregnancy. LMWH is preferred as it does not cross the placenta and is effective for thromboprophylaxis and anticoagulation in pregnant women, especially those with prosthetic valves. Why not the others? B. Immediate induction of labor: There is no indication for induction of labor in this case, as the patient is 37 weeks pregnant and may still benefit from transitioning to LMWH. Induction would only be considered if there were obstetric or medical concerns related to the pregnancy, which are not specified here. C. Immediate lower segment cesarean section (LSCS): A cesarean section would not be immediately required based on the patient's current condition unless there were complications such as fetal distress or other obstetric indications, which are not mentioned here. D. Continue the same medication: Continuing warfarin in pregnancy is contraindicated, particularly in the third trimester, due to the risks it poses to the fetus.

questions.text: Which drug acts on the letter mentioned X?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The diagram illustrates a portion of the fibrinolytic pathway, which is responsible for the breakdown of blood clots. In this pathway, Plasminogen is converted into Plasmin by Plasminogen activators (Plg activators). Plasmin then acts to degrade Fibrinogen and Fibrin, leading to the dissolution of a clot. The letter 'X' in the diagram is depicted with two red inhibitory arrows: one arrow indicates that 'X' inhibits the conversion of Plasminogen to Plasmin, and the other indicates that 'X' directly inhibits Plasmin. This combined action signifies that 'X' is an agent that inhibits fibrinolysis, essentially preventing or slowing down the breakdown of blood clots. Among the given options, Aminocaproic acid is a known antifibrinolytic drug that specifically works by inhibiting plasminogen activators and, to a lesser extent, directly inhibiting plasmin, precisely matching the inhibitory role of 'X' in the diagram. In contrast, Tenecteplase is a thrombolytic drug that acts as a plasminogen activator, promoting fibrinolysis, which is the opposite of 'X's' action. Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents clot formation but does not directly affect the fibrinolytic pathway as shown by 'X'. Similarly, Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug that inhibits platelet aggregation and is not involved in fibrinolysis in this manner. Therefore, based on its depicted inhibitory function, 'X' represents Aminocaproic acid.

questions.text: A patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia developed flushing, gout, hyperglycaemia, and raised liver enzymes. Which drug is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nicotinamide Explanation: The patient developed flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes, which are characteristic side effects of niacin (nicotinic acid), commonly used for hypertriglyceridemia. Niacin (nicotinamide) can cause the following side effects: Flushing: This is a common side effect of niacin, especially when used in higher doses, due to vasodilation of blood vessels. Gout: Niacin can increase uric acid levels, potentially precipitating gout in susceptible individuals. Hyperglycemia: Niacin can cause insulin resistance and lead to elevated blood sugar levels. Raised liver enzymes: Niacin can cause hepatotoxicity, leading to elevated liver enzymes in some patients. Why not the others? A. Atorvastatin: Atorvastatin is a statin, and while it can cause muscle pain and liver enzyme elevation, it is not typically associated with flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia as described in the case. B. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate is a fibrate used for hypertriglyceridemia and can lead to elevated liver enzymes and muscle-related issues, but it is not commonly associated with flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia. D. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that is generally well tolerated and is not associated with flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient is suffering from frequent attacks of renal colic. Preferred anti-hypertensive drug is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hydrochlorothiazide Explanation: The patient is suffering from frequent attacks of renal colic, which is typically associated with kidney stones. In this context, the preferred antihypertensive would be hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic. Hydrochlorothiazide is often used for hypertension because it helps reduce blood pressure by promoting the excretion of sodium and water. Importantly, it can also help in preventing the formation of calcium-based kidney stones by reducing calcium excretion in the urine. Why not the others? A. Ethacrynic acid: This is a loop diuretic that can cause significant potassium loss and is not typically first-line for managing hypertension. It can also increase the risk of kidney stones due to its effects on calcium handling in the kidneys. B. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used for conditions like glaucoma and altitude sickness, not typically for managing hypertension. It may increase the risk of renal stones due to its effects on calcium and bicarbonate excretion. D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and is often used in conditions like heart failure or primary hyperaldosteronism. It is not typically the first choice for hypertension when renal colic (due to kidney stones) is also a concern.

questions.text: A 25 year od male presented to emergency th head trauma due to road traffic accident. In hospital, the patient developed seizures Emergency CT Scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mannitol Explanation: In a patient with cerebral edema following head trauma, mannitol is the diuretic of choice. It is an osmotic diuretic that helps reduce cerebral edema by drawing water out of the brain and into the bloodstream, where it can then be excreted by the kidneys. This action helps reduce intracranial pressure, which is crucial in managing patients with cerebral edema due to trauma or other causes. Why not the others? B. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and is not used for reducing cerebral edema. It primarily acts on the aldosterone receptors and is more commonly used for conditions like heart failure or hyperaldosteronism. C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can be used to manage fluid overload but is not as effective in managing cerebral edema compared to mannitol. It may have some role in reducing intracranial pressure, but it is not the first-line choice for cerebral edema. D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and is not typically used for acute cerebral edema. It works on the distal convoluted tubule and is more commonly used for hypertension and mild edema.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital. He presents with anxiety, tremors, and agitation after his last drink 24hours ago. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for control of alcohol withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lorazepam Explanation: The patient is presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, including anxiety, tremors, and agitation. These symptoms typically begin within 6-24 hours after the last drink in individuals who have developed alcohol dependence. The most appropriate treatment for controlling acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms is a benzodiazepine, such as lorazepam. Lorazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine that helps manage alcohol withdrawal by acting on the GABA receptors, providing sedation and anxiolysis while preventing withdrawal seizures and delirium tremens (DTs). It is commonly used in the hospital setting for this purpose. Why not the others? B. Fomepizole: Fomepizole is used to treat methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not alcohol withdrawal. It inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the toxic effects of methanol and ethylene glycol. C. Disulfiram: Disulfiram is used for alcohol aversion therapy. It works by inhibiting acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, causing a buildup of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed, which leads to unpleasant effects (nausea, vomiting). However, it is not used during alcohol withdrawal. D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used primarily for generalized anxiety disorder. It does not have the sedative or anticonvulsant effects needed to control alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: Why is atropine mixed with Diphenoxylate In combination medications?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate Explanation: Diphenoxylate is an opioid derivative used as an antidiarrheal agent. However, it has the potential for abuse due to its opioid-like effects (e.g., euphoria). To prevent this, atropine is added to the combination medication. Atropine is an anticholinergic agent, and in higher doses, it can cause unpleasant side effects such as dry mouth, tachycardia, and blurred vision. These side effects are intentionally included in the combination to discourage individuals from taking large doses of diphenoxylate to achieve a euphoric effect. In therapeutic doses, the atropine component has minimal clinical effect, but when taken in excess, it produces discomfort, thereby deterring abuse of the medication. Why not the others? A. Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate: This is not the main reason. While atropine may have some minor effects on the GI tract, its primary role is not to reduce diphenoxylate’s side effects. C. To enhance the antidiarrheal effect: The combination of diphenoxylate and atropine does not significantly enhance the antidiarrheal action of diphenoxylate. The purpose is mainly to prevent abuse, not to enhance efficacy. D. Atropine produces direct spasmolytic action: While atropine does have some effects on smooth muscle by decreasing spasms (due to its anticholinergic properties), this is not the primary reason for its combination with diphenoxylate. The main goal is to prevent abuse.
